reviewText: I used these to hang some terracotta tiles on a wall. The tiles only weigh about 2 lbs, so these strips may have been a bit of overkill-- they are good up to 9 lbs. I stuck one on the wall and then decided to remove it to see if it "removed cleanly" as the package stated. It came off my painted stucco walls without anything on the strip.They are simple to use and the instructions on the back of the package are pretty much idiot-proof. I'm not sure I'd actually hang a 9 lb object with one, but I think it would be safe if you used 3 strips. They do caution you to "not hang items above beds" on the package, so it seems like they (3M) are not too sure about the product's ability to hold securely. Or maybe they are just worried that people won't follow the instructions properly.

I purchased this bulb to extend the battery life of my dewalt 18v flashlight for night time work site utility.When Hurricane Sandy came through and took out our power for a week, this LED bulb was already installed in the flashlight, and it allowed almost constant usage for about 36 hrs before swapping out battery packs, which was pretty useful when no one in the state had power..It was slightly dimmer than the original bulb, but uses so much less power that its well worth it.
summary: Replaced the incandescent bulb in my dewalt 18v flashlight

reviewText: This flashlight's small size is what I wanted to have on my bedside stand.  I also wanted long-lasting battery life, since I don't really use the bedside flashlight very often but when I do, I really want it to work, such as power outages or a crying child in the night.I am not concerned with durability thanks to the metal construction and the way the clear part covering the bulb is encased (rather than being flush with the end of the flashlight).  The ability to narrow and widen the light beam is handy for different situations.  The button to turn it on is very easy to work, but not in a place that might get bumped while you're using it.Overall, this is an excellent quality flashlight that is sleek and useful.

reviewerName: Shana "That's my opinion- I could be wrong!"
reviewText: I ordered these for  husband, as he has bad allergies to something in his workplace and his hands are always breaking out and cracking. He has to wear vinyl gloves and as most anyone his hands will sweat under the gloves, so the doctor recommended using cotton glove liners. I had been ordering another brand of cotton glove liners here on Amazon and they were $12.00 for just a box of 25. When the supplier stopped carrying those, I found these cotton glove liners. You will get a pack of 60, a wonderful buy, especially if you qualify for the Amazon super-saver free shipping.These cotton gloves are like a very thin and soft cotton t-shirt material. They will fit nicely even under tight vinyl or latex gloves. These seem to be longer and cover more of the wrist than the last brand I bought which is great for my husband as he also breaks out on his wrists, so these will keep his skin more protected.You can rewash these (I'd recommend using the delicate cycle) and reuse them. Though, over time with many repeated washes the seams will come out around the web of the hand. Though, with the great price and the quanity you get these will last a long, long time.The only thing I don't like is that these liners are not hemmed at the bottom of the glove, as this causes fraying after a few washes. Though, most of the other liners we've used are not hemmed either. For this price we can live with it though.Overall, I'd highly recommend these for anyone for as use for a thin cotton glove or glove liner. I'll definitely reorder these when we need more.
summary: Great buy, great for using under vinyl/latex gloves

reviewText: I got this for the boat so the fuel won't go bad, but lawn mowers also go a long time without new gas as well.

I have tried this product several times and it has yet to function has advertised.  IMO it is a ripoff.  Just yesterday I thought it had gained my respect when it beeped atop a breaker during the second pass.  This tool is dyslectic because the breaker was located on the opposite side of the panel lower down.

First, I hate it when reviewers say things like "... and it's orange.." when it's very clear that the product is orange - tell us something we can't tell easily ourselves, something that adds value. But I'm about to do that very thing.Also, I'm going to compare it to a Kohler faucet (amazon product number B000MF882K, and looking at the picture of it may make what I say below more obvious) that I've had for a couple of years. This isn't going to be a con/pro review (because it's a nice faucet and I don't see any cons so much as I see "are you sure this is what you want issues"). So...1) This is an expensive faucet and while I haven't had it long enough to judge how it will hold up, it seems well made and the price suggests it should be. The finish is a nice lightly brushed stainless.2) I was used to the Kohler and I liked it. It's a similar idea: single handle control , and the head of the faucet pulls out to be used as a sprayer-on-a-hose. But a couple of differences that I notice (in two near-identical sinks): On this faucet, only the bigger head at the end pulls out and while that works OK, it seems more awkward to pull it toward me than on the Kohler, because it pulls downward, whereas on the Kohler the part that pulls out is the head and several inches of the neck, and it pulls out more horizontally (with openings stil pointing down), which provides a nice handle, and you are pulled the hose sort of straight out.2) Make sure that you don't have cabinets over the sink that are low enough that this might seem too tall. This isn't at all a criticism, and for most people it won't make a difference, but measure if you do.3) This is a slight criticism, though I'm not sure it's fair as the issue is clearly visible: The control knob being on the side (which is typical with these high, arching faucuts) means only using the right hand, and I've got friends that have faucets which this feature. I'm not wild about it, but what I notice with this model is that the handle seems smaller than others and I find it hard to adjust easily. To be fair, I'm a very tall guy with large hands.4) These type of faucets (with the sprayer built indo the machin faucet) tend to reduce the water pressure because the swivel capability of the head means that it uses an attachment with a small flow-through swivel area (I haven no idea what the correct terms are). However, this one seems to be less affected by that than the Kohler, which is nice.All in all, I like this faucet. I hope it's well made and at roughly $350 as I type this, it should be. I'll report back after I've had it longer.
summary: Lovely faucet, but a couple of things to think about

reviewText: These are a really nice set of household screwdrivers. The independent cap is really nice for turning metal screws like electrical wall plates or small electronic items. Speaking of small elec items, this set is practically unrivaled and will easily handle the vast majority of screws smaller than #2 phil and has small enough flat head for eyeglass screws, in fact there is 1 driver even smaller than the eye glass screws should u ever require it. I almost took a star for the chinsy canvas case but it does the job and I never thought I would keep screwdrivers in a case of any kind, since I'm often reaching for them, but in this case (heh, heh), it's actually pretty nice to have.

The wife and I bought a 2,000 square feet "fixer-upper" and had all new eaves and cedar siding installed.  After getting the quote for staining the siding and eaves ($10k) I decided to save some money and stain the siding myself.  How hard can it be, right?  After scrubbing the siding with a little wood brightener (a must-do for cedar siding), and taping off the windows and trim, I started applying stain with a brush.  Ten hours later, I had completed about 15% of my siding.  Wow, only 85% more to go.  Looks like I'm not going anywhere on vacation this summer.  In addition to the time, my arms and shoulders were fatigued and I certainly didn't relish the thought of doing the same thing the next day.  I immediately went inside, started researching sprayers, and settled on this unit.The unit is very easy to set up.  It takes less than a minute and requires no tools.  I can't speak to how the unit works with latex paint, but it works like a dream with stain.  You have to spend a little more time taping and masking EVERYTHING that will be near the sprayer.  The overspray is pretty well constrained by the unit but you will definitely get a little spray that misses your target area.  Taping and masking is a must!  Don't expect to just put a 2" piece of painters tape on the edge of the trim closest to the siding.  You will have to cover the entire window AND seal the edges with tape.  If you have any prize-winning azaleas in front of your house, cover those too.  That being said, once your done taping/masking, the actual spraying takes about 1/5 to 1/10 of the time that a brush takes.  And it is sooooo much more fun than using a brush.  AND SOOOOO much less fatiguing than using a brush.  There's no pushing stain into corners or going over the same spot 3 times with a brush.  The sprayer just lays down the stain.  You WILL have to back brush a little.  This means that you will spray on the stain to saturation and smooth the stain into wood with brush. It fixes the inevitable drips, puddling, sags, etc.  It sound like you're doing twice the work but trust me, you're not.  SMOOTHING out stain with a brush takes about 1/10 of the effort and time as APPLYING stain with a brush.The paint/stain container used on the sprayer seems small when you look at it and it does empty out fairly quickly.  The reason it empties out quickly is because you coat so much of your project so fast that OF COURSE its going to empty out quickly.  The reason a gallon of paint/stain seems to last longer when you're using a brush is because you aren't moving fast enough to use much.  My only (very minor) complaint is that the hose did pop out a few times.  No big deal, it pops right back in and doesn't hurt anything in the process.In my opinion, clean up takes the same time as using a brush.  Unless you're using disposable brushes and just throwing them away at the end of the day, you have to clean your brush just like you have to clean this sprayer.  For the oil-based stain I was using, I simply saturated a paper towel in mineral spirits and wiped down the machine.  After that I emptied the remaining stain from the sprayer's container back into the can and filled the container about 1/3 full with mineral spirits.  After vigorously swishing the container, I turned on the sprayer until the spray ran clear.  Finally, I took apart the spray head (by hand, no tools necessary, takes about 10 seconds) and put them in some more mineral spirits.  After wiping down the parts, I put humpty-dumpty back together and shoved him in his box.One last thing (and remember, I can only speak to using stain with this sprayer), no thinning was required.  I just poured the stain directly into the container, attached it to the unit, and away I went.  I HIGHLY recommend this machine!
summary: My arm and shoulder would like to thank the fine folks at Wagner

reviewText: Pros:1. Great quality2. Looks great3. Durable4. Best $10 spend on a flash lightCons:1. Feels a bit light weight2. Didn't care for the green button on the back3. Not nearly as bright as described, but it is very bright still.

The usual Stanley quality prevails -- these are well-made, solid chisels and punchs.  What did I expect?  Well, I expected the tools to be clean of rust or tarnish as delivered -- check.  I expected the protective yellow paint to be in good condition -- check.  And last but not at all least, I expect the actual edges to be sharp and square -- check.  For the price, this is a must-buy, even if you only need one of these once a year.

Pros:Powerful brightFocusableTwo types of power (AAA or rechargeable lion)FIve modes (High-Medium-Low-SOS-Strobe)Cons:Lion charger came a bit broken... it was a little broken around the middle seam, but nothing that a piece of tape couldn't fixLast mode is remembered too long... like most lights, tapping the power button cycles through its five modes. However, even after being left off for an extended period of time (less than hours, but more than a few minutes) it just picks up where you left off the last time you were cycling through its modes. This leads to lots of annoyance when you go to turn it on expecting it to have reset to High mode, and instead find it in strobe or SOS.Conclusion:You get what you pay for. All of the advertised power, but you sacrifice a little quality and function.
Home Depot and Lowes wanted almost $6 a piece for halogen lamps. These are the better Xenon at $3 ea shipped to my door!
summary: Half the price of the big box stores

reviewText: I just received the TK35 so I will defer commenting on battery life until a future date when I have more time to test and write about run times. The overall construction of the TK35 is very well done with tight fitting screw threads, a fairly solid feeling battery holder and drop-proof sturdiness (already dropped it onto the hard tile floor). I have not invested in the rechargeable batteries yet so I am using CR123's since I them on hand for other lights. Battery loading into the holder is fairly easy and the holder only fits into the body of the light one way to avoid reverse polarity which is a nice feature.For output comparisons, I used a Fenix P2D (180 lumens), Fenix TK10 (190 lumens), Life-gear 3-Cree (360 lumens), and a Terralux 4-D Maglight upgrade (600 lumens). I mainly focused on comparing the TK35's turbo mode with the brightest modes available in the aforementioned lights and the TK35 clearly outshines all of them. I used to think the Terralux 600 lumen output was unparalleled but disliked the physical size of a 4-D light and I now have a light that fits in the palm of my hand with more output! The output of the TK35 is fairly even with no significant rings or dark spots that I can notice. I do notice that the output color temperature of the TK35 differs from other Fenix LED lights. The TK35 I received outputs a "warmer" slightly yellower light than the other Fenix lights I own which has more pure white outputs. This is not a problem, I just got used to seeing pure white outputs so I was not used to seeing the warmer/yellower output of the 35. This might just be a personal preference as the output is so much brighter and the warmer light actually gives things a more natural look.My only main complaint is with the size and shape of the TK35. The round head seems to make it head-heavy even with batteries loaded and while not a problem, the rectangular/skinnier main body where you grasp and hold the unit is a little awkward compared to a circular/tubular light. I suggest using the included lanyard as I have already dropped the unit trying to operate the rear switches with one hand. Again, this is probably just personal preference and the light as a whole is an awesome performer. I just can't wait to use it longer and in real-outdoor situations. Overall I am very pleased with my purchase and recommend this light to others looking for a mega-bright LED torch.

Want a cheap pair of jogging glasses for low light/night?  These are good - don't hurt your head, keeps the bugs out of your eyes, and don't fog up too bad (the shape permits air flow).  I've run about 10 times with these and have had no issues.  They don't squeeze my noggin too hard, but I have a narrow face.Cost-effective means of eye-protection.  I don't have cheap eyes, but when running, those tiny gnats make me crazy when they kamikaze themselves into my retinas.

Bought for cutting in kitchen; IMO better for outside work as they are "bulky." The tops should have been covered with protective material; cuts don't happen on top of hands? Not having tops of hands covered scares me. Beware of this. A bit expensive too IMO.

This product is short enough to wrap around the handle of a tool bucket or tuck into a bag of power tools.  The cord is pliable and heavy duty.  It has quite the temperature range it can operate in ( -32F to 125F).  The connection points and the GFI junction are all well-constructed.  Edges of the three plug are all rounded (no sharp corners).  While so far only light use this appears quite durable.This one is hanging off my husband's tool bucket but I will probably buy a second to carry in our travel trailer.

Well, these are somewhat cheezy home-owner sockets. Probably fine for the occasional user.Things I like: (1) they are 6-point sockets which make for stronger sockets than 12-point, (2) they use the Snap-on Flank-drive pattern which may reduce rounding off fasteners, (3) machining and finish are OK, (4) the socket rail they come on is very handy.Not-so-good things: (1) the machining and finish is not as good as Stanley or Performance Tools which are both pretty inexpensive alternatives, (2) they just have that not-very-strong "look" to them.In sum: a reasonable low-torque home-owner socket set.My favorite inexpensive alternative: Performance Tools impact socket set. Right now, Amazon doesn't sell the 3/8"-drive metric set, but here is the 1/2"-drive metric impact set:http://www.amazon.com/Performance-Tool-Mechanics-M593DB-Metric/dp/B000Q6NJ9M/ref=sr_1_15?s=power-hand-tools&ie;=UTF8&qid;=1334259459&sr;=1-15The impact sockets will clearly last the average hand tool user a lifetime.
summary: Ok socket set for the price

reviewText: I absolutely love Channellock tools that are made in the USA but Channellock quality control is starting to slip! This tool was made in the USA but did not receive the same attention to detail that I have come to expect from past purchases. That's the reason for knocking it down one star. They will work fine but for those tool aficionados out there I will try to give an honest report. The first flaw I noted was that the jaws do not line up. Mine were offset by 1/16". I think this is a big concern since the pliers are designed for ignition work that require precision & misaligned jaws do not fit in this category. There is no way to permanently correct this flaw since the pliers are riveted together instead of the former nut & bolt method so you can't adjust or tighten them to correct the problem, Closer tolerance machining would fix the problem. I can force the jaws to line up by slightly twisting the grips in my hand but I don't think I should have to do this. They should line up naturally when closed. The next flaw on my purchase was the rubberized coating on the handles did not fully cover the the ends. You can clearly see the metal underneath. It almost looks like it could have used one or more dips in the hot blue handle coating tank. The final flaw was the machining on the side of the metal jaw. It was sloppy at best with visible imperfections. I ran my pair across my wire wheel and applied a fresh coating of clear lacquer to dress up their appearance. Bear in mind that tools are individually crafted and you could get a pair that is perfect but I am stating the condition that mine arrived in. If purchasing from a brick and mortar store I would have passed this pair and pulled another one off the rack from behind. I did find the handles a little skinny making them uncomfortable to hold compared to the Irwin model that is approx half the price. The tool is designed to be small but could be constructed with slightly thicker rubber handles to make them easier to hold similar to the Irwin handles on their comparable product. I would buy again but will avoid buying sight unseen over the mail.

This is the first frosted (non-clear) E12 chandelier style bulb that I have purchased.  I like the bulb.While is has a medium white color (~3000K) the frosting dissipates the point-source of the light making it a bit more useful for indoor lighting (I don't usually use a 3000K white light indoor but the frosting helps here).  It should also work well for outdoor lighting if you want the non-filament frosted-look.  Like with other bulbs I would like to see this also without the pointed tip (my subjective view here) and possibly in a smaller size and/or warmer color, for more indoor use.
summary: Nice bulb with frosting to help tame the 3000K color

reviewText: You get what you pay for. I have tried so many of the cheap imported testers that work for a short while and then breaks for no apparent reason. I'm happy to find a domestic product and I'll pay the extra. This tester covers most household batteries. I like the feature where it puts a load on the battery to test its integrity, not just the voltage. A little care when removing the probe,I feel this is the weakest link, and it should be around for years.

On occasion, I will assemble things in the house.  Furniture, toys, Christmas trees; I fix everything in the house from toys to outlets to the boiler (not really).  I see all kinds of build quality, and this is an exemplary instance of great design poorly implemented.My neighbor has a twenty-year old version of this, in the 550-lb capacity size.  Durable, solid, and well-used.  He lent it to me when I was building my firewood rack this summer, and it made the job easy.  I immediately told my wife, "This is all I want for Christmas".Well, I got more than this, but I did get it, a 350-lb version from a big box.  I had some molding to install, so I decided I'd take ten minutes to assemble it and see if I could use it.A half-hour later, I discovered it would not open wide enough to fit the miter box and hold it between the boards.  I could have used the plastic stoppers, but one of the legs was broken on shipment.  And, I was already frustrated with the assembly process.The instruction pictures are too small.  Skip the four languages of useless text, just ship bigger pictures next time.  I did figure out which cross plate went where, after doing it wrong.  And the edges and bends of the metal were not clean or precisely angled on one side.  In short, a cheap and poorly-made version of a well-designed tool.I'll use it, and make it work, but I have little expectations of it lasting very long.  Twenty years might be out of the question.  Still, if it helps me on my 2009 projects, it'll be well worth it.  And I still appreciate the gift!-C
summary: Get past the poor quality and make it work.

reviewText: Read the instructions carefully by 2 people, but still cannot finish putting it together, so we search online for youtube instructions.The steps are not very complicated, but the instructions are unclear (difficult to understand what needed to be done), the print are also quite small, difficult to read.Parts not labelled, so difficult to check whether all parts/screws are in good orderPros: foldable, easy to store, affordable, free shipping, came with 4 plastic holdersCons: badly written instructions, parts not systematically labels (A, B, C...etc)
summary: Ok quality but not easy to put together

reviewText: A $47.00 light-bulb!!! I must be crazy. Well we'll see.It has a nice color balance and good dispersion But two things are not as advertised. First it is definitely not as bright as a sixty watt incandescent - more like a forty. Secondly it is not instant on like an incandescent. It comes on instantly at about half power and then goes to full brightness after a second or two. It's good enough that I would replace all my incandescents except for the price.I have a light just above my front door that I leave on all the time. It is in a fixture so I have always used indoor bulbs. The fixture takes an incandescent well but I had tried an LED before and it wouldn't fit. I have also used the compact fluorescents. At my electricity rate it's easy to calculate that this six watt LED will pay for itself compared to a sixty watt incandescent in about a year. Now that I see that it's more like a 40 than a 60 I guess it will take a year and a half. If this super expensive bulb fails before a year and a half I won't feel too smart. We'll see.At this price it makes sense near my front door but nowhere else. I have fluorescents in the kitchen, halogens in the bathroom and a decorative incandescent in the dining room. I have a couple incandescents here and there and a couple compact fluorescents but none of them is on for many hours a day. At it's present price this bulb would take decades to amortize it's initial expense through electricity savings except in my one always on front door fixture.Most of the people who have bought these so far I suspect are environmental wackos making a some kind of statement. I'm a bit more rational.The biggest benefit it has to deliver for me is lower hospital bills. I have to climb up a ladder to change this bulb. When I do this I risk falling off. I've never fallen off the ladder changing that bulb before but I have fallen while painting the garage. I'm nearing seventy and and 300 pounds. I don't need that kind of excitement anymore.If this bulb lasts as long as I hope, I will have saved maybe a dozen trips up that ladder - that's worth forty seven dollars.
summary: About as Bright as a 40 Watt Incandescent

reviewText: I bought this to use with my electric snowblower, and so far it has worked out well. Despite it being ridiculously cold outside, this cable retains its flexibility. It's a little heavy compared to a standard 100' cable, but that's completely understandable given its purpose. I have no fears about this cable getting cut or tearing because of how thick it is. There's no way this will fit into a standard cable reel, so I'd probably bypass that route if you were planning on it. However, it fits just fine on my Rubbermaid FastTrack Utility Hook.
I've had a DeWalt angle driver for a decade. This battery made it good as new and saved me the cost of a replacement driver at three times the cost.
summary: Good battery. Fast to charge and long charge retention

reviewText: NICE DURABLE SET, in okay retainers. I always throw them in a small baggie, and then into my tool box, so I don't risk loosing one out of the retainer. I like the longer handles, for greater torque, and they also give longer reach. I suggest that you buy them...

Bought this at a local store, but am really happy with it so figured id post a review here.  I had never routed anything before, and wanted to get a tool that would be a reasonable size and not too much of an investment in case I never got much future use out of it.  I wasn't sure how much power I'd need to do things like 3/8" round overs.  I bought this one because the all metal base seemed to possibly be stiffer than some of the larger and more powerful routers in the stores, that had plastic bases (granted the bases also were larger).Ive found that this unit has more than enough power to put a nice and consistent edge on a piece of hardwood (oak), and the system to set depth is fairly straightforward and easy to use.My only complaint, if I had to stretch for one, is that the base is a little small, so I did find myself inadvertently tilting the router a bit, and/or not having truly optimal contact with the workpiece.  My results still came out perfect, as I just went back and did it again.  I think that a few more cm of base area would possibly make a big difference, as might some kind of bullseye level to help ensure that Im certain the unit is flat on the workpiece.For $99, again, can't go wrong for doing any reasonable sized work.  If I was doing a big project or needed more intricate work, Id consider a larger unit with a table, like the >$200 Bosch units.  But for finish work on 1" type wood stock, I don't think there is a better value for a quality tool.
summary: Couldn't be happier as a first router purchase

reviewText: Hubby followed the simple installation directions – his thoughts were that it was considerably easy to install. The materials are of high quality, well constructed, and durable. The bright lights cover the majority of our backyard. However, depending on shape and size of the area you would like covered multiple units may be needed.

AS SOON AS I RECIEVED MY MILTON PLUG, I REMOVED THE OTHER BRAND OF MY AIR HOSE.GUESS WHAT NO MORE AIR LEAK ..I'VE CHANGE ALL MY PLUGS ON MY TOOLS AND AIR HOSE TO MILTON.. I ADVISE EVERYONE TO DO THE SAME...

I highly recommend this, better than I thought it would be and at a great price. I was tired of trying to balance a magnifier, tweezers, light, hold my hand still, etc. and this device is pretty nice. It does have a sharp edge that can rest uncomfortably on the forhead but the two nuts on the side can be finger-tightened down and prevent it, or it could be sanded down. The headlight takes two AAA's and is a little finiky regarding battery contacts; but it works. It has an on/off switch, light angle adjustments (side to side and up and down), and the whole light unit comes off if not needed. The mag. unit has a fixed lens, a flip-down doubler, and a loupe for the right eye that is very strong. Optics are plastic but very clear. Use a wet lens cloth. I will give one as a gift to my son's family and I recommend this over the other SE model. The headband adjusts with the simple twist of a knob in back. Durability will be a reason to update but I am pretty impressed so far. Great for splinters and small models (I work with Z-Scale trains-very little. Focal length is short but that is expected. Model glue would be bad on a plastic lens, as would Kleenx or toilet paper (or paper towels!). Very comfortable and easy to use.
they are awesome, the light is very comfortable and very nice, they are at a good price the quality is awesome
As beginner in knife sharpening the sharpening guide is a big help. This is a great buy and I recommend it to everyone.

Actually I meant to say these work fine for cutting open those maddeningly pesky plastic clamshell-like enclosures so many items come encased in these days. Or try a really big pair of Fiskars scissors, like Amazon's "Fiskars 9 Inch Premier Titanium Nitride Shop Shears (12-96536984)."
summary: Just what you need to open Amazon packages.

reviewText: A friend of mine, when he saw it, called it "the mother of all flashlights" and I think he was right.  The Coast HP314 model.  Everything from the flashlight down to the packaging is first-rate.  It comes complete with a pouch and shoulder strap and the latter is helpful as, while the flashlight itself is not that heavy, it is a bit unbalanced and the strap prevents unneeded strain on your wrists.  With successive clicks, the light goes through a cycle of high intensity, low intensity, and strobe.  By adjusting the front section outward or inward, you can set the proper focus.  It is certainly not an "everyday flashlight" but for anyone who needs to shed a lot of light a long way (e.g., emergency rescue personnel), its 1132 lumens and range of over 2000 feet would make a huge difference.  A specialty product for a special audience but superb for the right niche.
this saw blade to me should be sharper and last longer  I put down a laminate and before I was the blade was very dull

These lights were used to light a basement area that does not have a light switch, and they do this well.  Brighter than a kid's nightlight, these make good choices for hallway or utility lights in dark areas.  The sensor is responsive and dims according to nearby light.
This square is, um, square. The head slides smoothly and locks easily. Not the same quality as the $100 model used by some woodworkers, but I've found this square to be reliable and accurate.

The Rockler Table Featherboard is a great product. I bought one to use on my table saw; it does what it is supposed to do and does it very well. I have been using it for about six months and during that time it has functioned flawlessly. I have recently purchased a router table; the featherboard is great for holding my work against the table fence. I will be purchasing a second featherboard for use on the out feed side of the table saw blade and the out feed side of the router bit to guarantee that the work is guided securely. It fits the  inch miter slot on both machines; as you turn the clamp knobs the miter slide opens and clamps the featherboard securely in the miter slot.

These anti-UV gloves fit me well.  I normally wear medium gloves.  My bones are fine and my fingers are long and skinny.  To give you an idea, my wedding ring is a size 6.  The material isn't especially stretchy around the fingers, so they may not fit someone with larger hands.

Recently got this tool, after countless recomendations from friends, family and my own research (internet review, etc). For $99 this is an awesome deal. The saw has the power for house projects and much more, I built some cabinets and a deck, this tool was by my side the whole time. A+The blad can be installed right side up or upside down, the trigger is sturdy enough to keep you from accidentally going full speed. There's no variable speed knob, you simply use the trigger, the softer the squeeze, the less power and vice versa.Here's what you get: 1 Saw of course, intructions, that's it. It comes in a nice hard case, which doesn't have much room for other tools or PPE.I didn't notice any issues, no over heating, etc. Make sure you follow the instructions carefully and you should be fine. Nothing much to say, I'm not a professional builder, but I can handle my own, so if you are just like me, a regular guy, this tool will be more than enough.By the way, I bought theseMilwaukee 49-22-1129 12-Piece Ultimate Demolition Sawzall Blade Setand they work great. I only used one wood and one metal for my entire project!
summary: Powerful Tool. Nice Hard Case. Great Price.

reviewText: I replaced three exterior light switches with these to make it easier to have our lights go on when it is dark outside.  There are cheaper ways to do that, but this is really hassle free, once you have it set up.  If these cost a lot less, I'd replace all the switches in the house with them, and would never have to run through the house turning switches off again.I have no complaints with this, and recommend it for some use cases (such as exterior lights).
summary: Works really well.  If they cost a lot less I'd replace every switch in my house.

reviewText: I have an 18-year-old stepson who often can't be bothered to shut the toilet lid gently. Needless to say, that's not a problem anymore.The lid works exactly as expected, and it comes with very good mounting hardware. Not much to dislike.

I used this to paint my car.  Admittedly I had no idea what I was doing or how to use this gun.  The car has some texture now, but I'll say this, the texture is very consistent and looks pretty awesome.  Think along the lines of the SR-117A Nighthawk.  Just a slight matte texture.  Pretty bad-a$$.Honestly I think this gun is fine.  It's fit and finish is nice and it feels well built, for a cheaper spray gun.  I have no complaints.
Really helps keep the dust down. I use a 1.5 gallon wet/dry vac with it and it works. I would buy this againPat

I can't say enough good things about this little vacuum it has helped me out so many times and cleaned up so much stuff if it broke tomorrow I would not hesitate to buy another one this gets high reviews for reason and that reason is it's a fantastic product you will not be disappointed

I have a cheap kenmore range.  The paint on the backsplash wore off with cleaning.  I used this to refinish that surface.  Lasted 2 years under heavy use, hours of boiling pot next to it, daily use and occasional cleaning with degreaser.  The paint is coming off, though.

This "broken arm" as it is called in our area is WONDERFUL!  You can reach and twist, and turn the brush so easily to another direction.  It is also so very easy to remove a brush and change to another of better size or width simply pull it out, and push in another, yet it doesn't twist on you while being used, I love that is secure!  It is capable of adding an extension for height.

Doubt you could slip past the TSA with it on your key ring but it really does look like any other key until you see the thumb nail slot on the blade. The blade will really take an edge as well. Try Spyderco's knife sharpening kit on here...puts an edge on about anything....especially your kitchen knives and pocket knives...razor sharp.

I use these strips to hang a small dry erase board (about 15"x11") on our kitchen wall.  My first attempt resulted in the board being a little crooked. I removed the dry erase board to adjust it and one of the strips came off the wall. I still had one strip left, fortunately, since once they come off the wall, they won't restick.  For my second attempt I used a level to make sure that I got it straight since, unlike a nail or thumb tacks, it's more difficult to make small adjustments with these strips.  Got it straight, and the board has been hanging steady for about three weeks now.  Very nice.  Worked so well that I decided to buy a second, identical board for our game room to keep score on.  The walls in our game room have more of a glossy paint.  The board fell within 24 hours.  I ended up using the larger version of this product, and those ended up working fine.  So you will need to look at your individual situation and possibly go for the larger strips if you have a heavier item or a more slick surface.  Nice alternative to nails, but you have one shot at getting the strip to stick.  If it comes off, it is used up and you are out a strip.  That makes this solution a bit expensive.  Do note that you can see the white strips from the side (unless you are able to mount the strips on your picture a couple of inches from the edge.  If you are mounting a nice picture in a nice place, it might look a little tacky.
summary: Good alternative to nails for small pictures and posters, but be careful on glossy paints

reviewText: I have a thing for flashlights since there is never one handy when you need it.  But I think I'll keep this one nearby.The pros:Love the ergonomic handle--one side of the handle is lumpy so you'll know you've grabbed the right side for thumb-to-button action.It's oval shaped--unlike all my other flashlights.It's white (and not black!) so it's easier to find in dim light.Has a great carabiner-like clip on the end to hang it easily.It is EXTREMELY bright with 6 LED lights in a small oval, yet the beam is still a nice circular light like you'd expect.It's solar powered!  It has a pretty large panel (4.75 x 1.5") for a flashlight.The oval edges are notched so it sets flat and does not roll.The cons:It feels rather cheap and not very rugged, as if I dropped it the plastic would shatter.The on-off button seems very weak--not like it will hold up to much use.The carabiner clip needs manual pushing to close it fully, not sure why this wouldn't just snap shut by itself.The glow in the dark ring is nice in theory, but this ring is so skinny I doubt it would really help me find it in the pitch dark, and natural light for several days didn't seem to brighten it as much as shining another flashlight at the ring did.The glow ring didn't last long at all.It comes with a battery pack you have to install, which was pretty easy but getting the wires to fit under the door fins was a small pain.The replacement battery pack will cost you $9.95 + $6.95 s/h!  Not sure how long it will last but I could buy another few flashlights with that amount of money.Overall it seems very nice and handy--ergonomic even--and I like that, but when the battery pack dies, that may be the end of it for me.

A nice set of punches and chisels. I am mostly a hobbist and these work great for me. I don't believe this set is for someone who would be using them 40 hours a week, but for the "part-timer" they are great!

First, the bad.  I was a bit unimpressed by the build quality of this vac.  It has a cheap feel to it and the hose is a bit harder to latch in than competitors.  I don't use the attachments all that much and my old Shop Vac came with "on board storage" which is conspicuously absent from this model.  It won't take long to lose the attachments if you use them infrequently, especially in a shop.  Also, the blower "port" is handy but it would be nice if it pointed up instead of behind.  The vacuum is so small, powerful, and close to the ground that it can end up kicking up dirt and debris before you have a chance to get to it with the vacuum.On the upside, it is definitely smaller and lighter than I was expecting, which is nice, and it does a great job acting as a vacuum.  I use it around the garage/shop, the house, and for my truck with stellar results.  It's definitely powerful and will suck up just about everything from pens to pieces of paper to big spills.  It's hard to quantify this thing's power, but it can do MUCH more than I thought it would!  I can suck up just about anything -- good or bad -- and more than a few times has captured a rogue dog toy or two.  It can even get those hard-to-reach dust bunnies since you only have to get close-ish.  A few minor design tweaks and a longer cord would make this thing just about perfect.In the end, the price seems a bit high, but I feel the warranty allays any concerns that you may have.  Shop vacs don't rely on the container to create suction, so the build quality only becomes an issue for durability.  I'm very pleased with it and have ended up using it a LOT more than I thought I would.  Every home needs one of these!
summary: Powerful vacuum just a few tweaks away from perfect!

reviewText: WELL, A LOCAL BIG BOX WANTED $5.99 EACH, SO I GOT 10 BULBS FOR $7.50 WHICH MAY SEEM LIKE OVERKILL, BUT IT WORKS OUT TO $ 0.75c A BULB! WILL NEVER NEED TO PURCHACE THESE BULBS EVER!

Seriously, this is one bright light for the size. It runs on three AAA batteries, which is a problematic amount (two would be better, as these are often sold in four-packs), but since the flashlight comes with two sets of batteries to begin with, and runs on said AAA batteries forever, I really can't complain.While the white LEDs are so bright that the light could be used as a 'stun-type' weapon, the red LED bulb is just about right for seeing in the dark in a gentle, general way. Inside a tent, I use the red light as a lantern, standing the flashlight body up on one end.It's helpful that the buttons have a tactile difference so you can tell which is which in the dark. The red button for the red light is smooth. The black button for the white lights is scored, which you can feel by running a fingernail over it.I appreciate the feel of the flashlight, with its sturdy black anodized body, and a solid, balanced weight in my hand. I have small hands, so this flashlight feels about right for me. For larger hands, this might be considered too small.The body of the flashlight is scored for secure gripping, flat on the both ends, and has the light buttons up at the top/front of the barrel. There's a small keyring on the bottom. A black lanyard attaches to the ring, and there's a tiny carabiner for the far end. I clipped the carabiner through the back strap of the flashlight holster - this ensures I will always have the nylon holster handy.The holster itself is made of black nylon canvas with a Velcro'ed top flap and webbing belt loop.RECOMMENDATIONOverall, this is a very well-considered kit. You get the LED flashlight with two lighting options, batteries, an extra set of batteries, a holster, and a lanyard and carabiner, all together. I'm very happy with the sturdy feel, ease of use, and incredible brightness of this flashlight.I've seen these kind of tactical torches sold for outrageously high prices, and I can't imagine those lights are a whole lot better than this one. Highly recommended!
summary: Intensely bright, rugged LED light, good for smaller adult hands

reviewText: I've used this spray on the under carriage of our RAV 4  to eliminate grunts and groans. It works better than expected.I have used competitive products on this and other cars on the door "rubbers" and been satisfied, but this is the one for underneath.

First, to this sellers credit, all the issues I'm going to list below have been promptly and professionally responded to and resolved. All together I bought four of these.The quality of the flashlight is outstanding. I have a LedLenser I bought here on Amazon for over $100 (P7) and the LED flashlight that comes with this kit is 90% as bright as the P7. And that's not just my opinion, that's using a light meter bought here on amazon as well. The light is a nice bright white and as has a useful range of about 1/8 mile (660') (reflective range about double that.) The one down side is one of the LED flashlights had a defective battery holder, which was promptly replaced. The flashlights have a beam adjustment for range; short and wide or long and narrow or anything in between. At the long range, the light pattern is a perfect square. As you pull it back, it goes out to a round spot and the further you pull it back it goes to a wide flood. The switch goes low-off-high-off-high flashing-off. The high flashing mode is insanely effective if you want people to see you.Now the bike mount. It functions well, but I did have to use some old vinyl 7/8" tubing to act as a spacer on my 22mm handle bars. Its pretty easy to adjust and goes up and down and left and right. You may also notice it's "sloppy." If so, you pull out the little rubber pad and there is a screw in there that you can tighten to take up the slack. I had to tighten all 4 I bought.Now here is the problem. I bought 4 total, 2 of which broke. The seller is replacing both. One broke in the mail and one just broke on it's own. It was fine after a ride and then the next day I came out and it had snapped during the night. The problem is the plastic hinges seem to be a bit brittle. They broke right were the metal pin goes through them. It's really very thinly molded in that area. Two are still hanging in there and we'll see how the two new ones do. I strongly suggest only tightening the nut just enough to keep the mount from turning.I put two on each bike. One is focused long range and the other wide range. You can easily be seen a mile away, and with the two of them like I have them setup, close stuff is visible and long range is also very well lit at least out to 1/8th mile.Based on the price, (I paid $25 each) I don't see how you can go wrong. The flashlight is really equal to a $100 LedLenser P7 (okay 90%) and if the bike mounts hold up, then that's a bonus.

Negatives:  for me the clip is on backwards, you can't clip it to the brim of your ball cap.  If you do you will go blind.Positives:  very bright light, impressive. I'm not an expert, don't do alot of woodworking, and up til recently nothing really fancy.  But with this awesome tool I feel as if the sky's the limit.  This is the 2nd Bosch tool I've purchased from Amazon, which rocks by the way, and I like the feel, the heft, and the well made features of their tools.  I have to be honest and say I'm a little intimidated by this router, but found upon use that it cuts really smooth.  Of course using 1/2 inch shank bits that are extremely sharp probably help quite a bit towards that smooth operation.  Now that I have this router, and soon to own the Bosch router table as well, which is also invaluable, and the edge cutting/circle cutting guide too, I don't know how I survived without one before now.  You almost have to have someway to brace this tool when cutting straight lines or trying to follow a certain pattern.  Even though it cuts through the wood like a hot knife through butter, it's a very hard to keep if from wobbling.  Good example of this is:  it's alot like trying to hold a camera steady while zooming in close and keeping it steady without using a tripod, and that's a camera without the new autosteady feature that the new ones all have.  My advice?  This is a must have tool, but when you buy it also budget for the edge guide tool, and plan on getting the table sometime along the way also.
summary: I'm a weekend handyman, but this tool I love!

My trusty Waterpik shower head has traveled with me from apartment, to duplex, to my house. And at about 11 years old, the connector started leaking and the head itself was looking rather hit, so it was time to replace it.My first thought was to buy another Waterpik, but at nearly twice the price, I decided to give the Peerless a shot. Thanks in no small part to the reviews here (and video!) I will say, I was hesitant about the removable head not having as many settings as my Waterpik. It wasn't until I had this installed that I was sure I had a keeper.It's a shower head, so you don't need to be a plumber to install it. Have anadjustable wrench? You're good to go. Have someteflon tape? Even better! The instructions were straightforward, and the project took all of about five minutes to complete.Once I turned it on, I was really surprised by the amount of water flow. Set to "both", this thing will drench you! Removing the head and replacing it is really easy and can be accomplished without blocking the nozzles and spraying water all over the place. Initially, I thought my reservations had been justified with the few settings on the removable head, but being able to have the fixed shower head going while using the removable head is so great, I don't care that it only has four settings. That pretty much sealed the deal right there."Why only four stars, then?" you ask? The overall design can really be improved. You have chrome going to brown plastic, back to chrome, back to brown plastic, and turquoise nozzles. I love the 80's as much as anyone, but I'm not all excited about stepping back in time when I take a shower. I didn't think it would bother me much when I bought it, but it really is kind of atrocious after having used it for about a month.I like the shower head too much to replace it, but if Peerless came out with an all-chrome model, I'd buy it in a heartbeat and give this to a friend. As long as you don't mind (or can live with) the way it looks, this is an awesome value.
summary: It's like getting more than you paid for.

I picked up this light to install near our front door, as a deterrent to burglars and graffiti scrawlers, as well as to provide some helpful light for opening the door. It works perfectly for that. It isn't as bright as a "wired" motion sensing light with flood lamps, but I see the light is merely a deterrent - someone will either be deterred by a light coming on or they won't.One unexpected benefit: three neighbors and/or passersby asked me if it was a camera, so burglars and others may think it is too. [Good]Motion detection works fine.It's easy to use and easy to install.Will be powered for a long time. I just started using this but I would guess this could theoretically last on the same batteries for a few years, assuming you bought a good brand of batteries. If you use rechargeable batteries, this unit will probably last a decade on the same batteries with charges in between some years. There's a reason for this, which I'll explain later.No need to do wiring yourself or hire an electrician if you're not handy.This will not rust since it's a plastic body.[Bad]Guess why the batteries will last a really really long time? This isn't very bright for outdoor motion lights, which kind of kills the whole point.Batteries not included: D Batteries are over ten dollars for a 4-pack (currently Amazon sells it at twelve dollars before tax). Rechargeable ones are even more.Feels Cheap: With the batteries installed, I feel like I could break it if I get too careless adjusting it.Expensive: Even before you factor in the ten dollar cost of non-rechargable batteries, this is not a good deal. The lumen output is just poor compared to the solar powered models. Moreover, when you do factor in battery cost then the cost is about equal to solar powered LED spotlights, so in most cases this product just doesn't make any sense unless they lower the price.[Misc]My unit did not come with screws and anchors. However, the manufacturer says that it should be included and if it's missing to call their customer support number and they will mail it to you.[Verdict]I'd only get this if you have a spot that doesn't have access to either sunlight or an electrical outlet, which is probably great for places like Alaska and Scandinavia. If not, then I'd get something else.

First: I am a purchaser for a factory in Missouri. We have approximately 35 employees in the plant, and probably about 10 who use these. Hearing protection is not required in our facility per OSHA guidelines, but we do offer these to our employees.Pros:These earmuffs are a fantastic compromise between hearing protection and music-playing capability. They dampen external noise, allowing for music to be played at a pleasant, SAFE volume.They are much better for a gritty factory or working environment than ear buds, which clog and irritate inner-ears in our experience here.They are easy to clean with alcohol wipes, and, if necessary, replacement padding is easy enough to come by.The headset itself seems to hold up well in our industrial environment.Cons: The only real issue with this product is the audio cable. The cords supplied with the earmuffs tend to wear out quickly, and or just go bad. I learned very quickly to keep extra cords from different vendors on hand as replacements. These audio cables are cheap - less than $5 to replace, but you should know this ahead. This is the reason for the -1 star.
summary: I buy these for factory workers

I was using aRidgid R7121 Drill, 1/2-Inch Spade Handle Mud Mixerto drill holes in freshly poured concrete for rebar for a large garage I was building. One hole would require me putting all my weight on the drill for about 10 minutes as it vibrated my wrists. Of course spade drills are designed for mixing wet mud, not drilling into hardened mud. And it would make the drill hot.I got tired of abusing my big mixing drills, and my wrists like that, so I got this Bosch SDS. I got it factory reconditioned from CPO. I could not tell it had been used other than the box was open. It drilled the same hole my spade drill took 10 minutes to do in 15 seconds.I've run this drill for hours doing nothing but 1/2" rebar holes and it doesn't get hot, just keeps going. No problems yet after a few buildings.SDS stands for slotted drive system. It uses a special kind of drill bit. Normal bits will not work without an adapter which I cover in the next paragraph. Basically you click a bit on, and the chuck locks it in place. Then only the bit is impacted in the chuck, instead of the entire chuck being impacted. Or to put it another way, only the bit moves while the chuck stays in place. This makes it a more efficient transmission of power, which is why SDS drills are all more powerful than traditional hammer-drills. Traditional hammer-drill chucks have more weight they need to move up and down.The drill has three settings. Drill only. Impact only. And drill and impact, like all SDS drills. And like all SDS drills the handle has vibration absorption. I won't lie and say Dewalt or Milwaukee are better or worse, I think those 3 brands stand hand-in-hand at the top, with Hilti standing above them, but also with a price tag twice as high.Since SDS drills are built to take abuse and high torque applications, they are also great candidates to use a hole saw with. But to use a hole saw you will need to buy theBosch 1618571014 SDS-plus Shank 3 Jaw Chuck with Integral. That "traditional" chuck will basically lock into the SDS chuck, so you will have two chucks doubled up. But then you can also use any other normal drill bit. Keep in mind if you have lots of smooth-shank-masonry-drill bits that you will need this chuck adapter if you want them to work in any SDS drill. And those traditional bits will not work as well as SDS bits, because then the drill has to move an entire chuck, just like traditional hammer drills.SDS max is not compatible with SDS+, MAX is basically for demolition and massive boring jobs. SDS plus and SDS+ is the same thing and is compilable with SDS.
summary: Goes through concrete as easy as pushing a bit into sand.

The SE45x has a great field of view..and extremely Comfortable Eye Relief.  If you are familiar with Micro-scoping tools, hand-lenses etc, you will more than appreciate the ease and versatility of this tool. The UV light sets this apart from most others in its Category, and is Invaluable when Identifying a specific zone of gems and minerals.The telescoping focus, is allot better at getting a comfortable view of anything you are looking at, versus the typical hand lense manual method.The frame and case are durable and easy to understand.  The battery life is what you can expect from any LED device, excellent.I use it for Mineral Identification, and the telescoping focus rock(no pun Intended), and is really nice.The LED is a bit different than advertised in that it does Visible light AND UV..So it really can be used for a variety of uses.The magnification is probably the best part.  It is really strong, and has the eye relief of the more expensive triplicates.  Eye relief, for those who do not know, is exactly what it sounds like...the ability of someone to view thru it for hours, without eyestrain and discomfort..If you are going to be using a Microscope or lens, pay attention to this..as it will inevitably be the most important option you will "feel" when using any tool of this type.Finally the Price cannot be beat.  I saw one review mention buying more than one, and I definitely would agree. At under $5.00 the shipping was more than the tool...so get several and make a friend happy!.Two things were different that advertised...It comes with two light sources, not just the one...A NET PLUS, and they shipped a 60x, not the 45x.  again a Net Plus.  Not sure if this was intended, so may want to get some now...before I buy them all up.  Giving these away to my Student friends, and selling the rest for $10.00 a piece..finders fee.In all seriousness I encourage everyone to do their own research, and if you are looking at my review for that reason..consider the research doe...BUY this.  I would tell you if it were crap.  I am equally hard on products that do not meet the level of quality that I need for field work.  I hope this helps, and feel free to contact me for any further Explanation or Opinion.Best Scope for the Money, best scope for eye-relief(within its Category--Will spend $50.00+ on a comparable Triplicate.i.e. Bauch/Laum, and the COOL FACTOR is top Notch.
summary: SImply the Best MultiFunctional Microscoping tube
