reviewText: The first thing that anyone looking to buy this product needs to know is that this device canNOT take the place of a heart rate monitor with a chest strap. If you're looking to monitor your heart rate while running (or doing any type of exercise), this is not the device for you. For that reason alone I think it's misleadingly labelled and marketed a bit deceivingly (most of the pictures of people using this device show them running with it... but you have to hold completely still in order for it to take your heart rate). For that reason alone I have to give it only 2 stars. If this was marketed as a watch with heart rate monitoring capability I would give it four stars.With that out of the way, it is a nice watch. It's got an attractive design and is incredibly easy to set up and to use. The display is large and so are the numbers so it's easy to read. If you want to use it as a stopwatch or an alarm it handles that easily.It's the heart rate monitor part that's disappointing. When it does work it's great - it's convenient to get your heart rate whenever you want. But even sitting completely still I've found it to work only about 50% of the time, which is pretty frustrating. If you are moving (even walking slowly) it will not work at all and will flash to the heart rate monitor screen for a second before flashing back to the clock. To me that should prevent it from being called a heart rate monitor.
summary: Misleadingly labelled, but it is a nice watch

reviewText: I needed a more pointed live center and liked the PSI.  Received super fast, solid packaged, super quality and performs flawlessly. Would recommend.

I am using it on the exhaust of a Buderus oil burner with direct vent (the blower is on the air intake side and it exhausts out the wall not up a chimney).Previously the techs had used the silicone sealant around all of the vent joints but it eventually wears away (poor installation I suspect).  So I replaced the silicone and covered it with this tape.  So far it has been pretty good and has reduced the sound of the burner substantially.As someone had described earlier, the glue does not stick once heated.  But like most metal tapes, you need to mold it to the shape of the pipe and so it stays pretty much were I wanted it to stay.  The ends will need some small wires wrapped around the flue to keep them in place.  Suffice it to say, using small pieces of this tape is not useful.  Longer runs are better, but around edges it tears easily so be careful.As far as the comment about the glue coming off, it sure does if you treat this tape like it blue masking tape.  You have to pull slowly and at the right angle.  If you feel or see it starting to break apart, change speeds or angle.  The glue doesn't know which side to stick to since it is metal tape and the same on both sides.The adhesive is not really good for 600degree and out gasses at this temperature.  I'm sure this will subside after a few weeks which is no problem (although the outgassing might be from the silicone, but I've never had this problem before).
summary: Know the characteristics of your tape - it's not the same as the blue painters tape

reviewText: Works in my 20 year old right-angle drill.

When my Rotozip worn out, I went to Dewalt's website to gather more information about this cordless rotary tool. Dewalt presents this rotary tool without a battery as in Amazon. However, whereas Amazon product description discloses this tool uses a Ni-Cad battery, Dewalt's website conspicuously conceal this important fact. As further example of DeWalt's non-disclosure of important product information, DeWalt's website reference an 18V XRP battery for this rotary tool but still left out the Ni-Cad information. Instead, the product description merely states that the DeWalt 18V XRP battery is compatible with all Dewalt cordless 18V power tools and has 40% more power than a standard battery. Not a single word is found anywhere describing the XRP as a Ni-Cad. By not providing important disclosures, DeWalt has intentionally mislead consumers into believing this battery could be a Li-Ion battery.Today's Lithium-ion battery is much superior to yesterday's Ni-Cad battery in terms of power density, lower weight, fast recharge, and negligible memory. So superior is Li-Ion to Ni-Cad that Ni-Cad tools and Ni-Cad battery are relegated to obsolete tools. DeWalt knows this, too.I was slowly warming up to DeWalt's brand of tools but this recent experience has taught me not to trust or buy a DeWalt tool. I am so glad I discover DeWalt's sneaky hide-and-seek business practice. Even more important, this experience has reinforced my loyalty to buying tools from Amazon.

This light is not only a work light, but while being positioned over the actual blade, acts as a true cutting alignment mark for your work piece.  The over head light casts a shadow of the saw blade right on the wood being cut.  This system seems as though it will not go out of alignment as it is securely mounted in O.E.M. mounting positions.  There is a separate on/off switch just behind the D-handle that controls the light and mounts on top of the saw blade replacing a cover that resides there.  Both items integrate  seamlessly into the saw, (mine a DW717 10" saw).  The reason I gave a rating of only four stars is because the light switch is a little difficult to install.  There is not much room for the wiring in the switch housing.  Be careful not to pinch the wires while screwing down the switch cover.  The shadow cast from the blade is not real defined until the blade approaches the work piece, unlike lasers that always throw a defined bright colored line on the work piece.

I have used my Ryobi drill well longer than I can remember for everything a drill requires, but batteries never last, i just needed one to use it my drill fit it like it should absolutely no issues just a quick charge and back to work. minor scuffs being used but at half off from a trusted seller is economical, never a bad buy as long as you know what your paying for.
summary: much needed and better than hand screwing

reviewText: This was delivered a day early yesterday to my mail box.  After filling the blue bottle as full as I could get without any spilling out, I then poured it into a glass Pyrex measuring cup and this blue bottle holds exactly 11 ounces, not one ounce more; so one ounce less than one and one-half cups of water.After using a few times, I find that I should have purchased at least two.  I still end up (no pun intended) using toilet paper and a wash cloth or small towel to clean up the water on toilet and my behind.  Never does any part touch your bottom but you can still spray clean the wand with bleach if you're unsure.I looked to see if a "large portable bidet" was available and found none.  My water source is either in the bathtub in front of me, meaning I would have to get up and step over to tub to refill, or purchase two and have another on hand as the sinks are separated in another room/section of the bathroom.  The top with the squirt wand is well designed with five holes on each side of a very small plastic bar and perfect sending a good sprinkle stream of water that you control and the wand inverts to fit into the bottle itself and if you wish, you can keep it in the little nylon bag that comes with it to keep out of site.  With the nylon bag and the wand not fitting tight or closed, there is very little chance of mold developing if not used for a while.  Simply rinse it out before the next use.7-16-13:  I came back to Amazon and purchased another one today.  I like it.

I replaced an earlier Kwikset electronic combination lock with this one.  The Kwikset was motor driven and batteries wore out too often.  This one works with a solenoid to engage/disengage the handle.  Overall a solid unit - stronger lock than the Kwikset.
I had never installed one of these before, but that didn't matter. It only took seconds to cut to length and apply. Months later, it's still working great.

After much disappointment with a portable drill many years ago, I've depended on my Craftsman Professional corded drill for my diy repairs and installations on our old house and our old rental building.  All too often, I've had to run a long extension cord to my project.  Often, the corded drill has been too large to fit into small spaces.  But, I'm stubborn; didn't want to be dependent on batteries.  However, batteries have changed for the better, so when I decided to take advantage of old flooring being replaced to screw down the creaky floorboards in a kitchen, I was very glad to have this lighter weight compact tool to secure the boards and still have charge left.  Compactness wasn't an issue in that first test, but at 8.5" from the tip of the chuck to the back of the casing, this Black & Decker will fit spots I wouldn't be able to reach with the corded drill.  And it won't give out in the middle of a job.

My home was built in 1990, in Florida. I guess back then the building code did not require GFCI outlets anywhere other than the garage. Anyway, I installed this in the kitchen for added protection. I agree with the reviewer that pointed out that it should have some attaching hardware so it won't come out of the socket when you unplug a device from it. This is the only multiple-outlet adapter I could find that was GFCI protected. Other adapters were Surge protected, which is not the same. The only other thing I've noticed is that the red light indicator stays illuminated during normal use and only goes out if there is a problem (ground fault). This is the opposite way other GFCI outlets behave. Their red light illuminates only when a fault has been detected. A non-issue. I gave it 4-stars only because of the inability to secure it to the wall. I would recommend

Decent bungee, but not the best I've used.  First time using one of them the plastic end of one hook broke off exposing the metal inside. I have had a similar set made by another manufacturer for years and never had one break yet.  All in all, these are pretty good for the price, but it is the value that rates 4 stars, not the quality.

So far, this switch is working great.Some points to consider:* The wall plate must be removed to access a button that is required to change a couple of settings, like the mode. I put the wall plate on, then had to take it off to switch to 'vacancy' mode.* Does not require a 'neutral' wire, but does require a ground.* Surprisingly noisy when it switches, but not a big deal.* I am using it in vacancy mode for a small kid's bedroom. It operates like a normal switch this way (with manual on) except that it can automatically turn the light off within a certain amount of time if the room appears it has gone vacant. I wouldn't want the light turning on when I walk in to check on him while he's sleeping.* Make sure the sensor has a good view of the room. Also, if it can see out the door, it might be an issue as people walk by the room.* I noticed that they also sell this unit at Lowe's.* I bought a new wall plate cover to go with this switch, but it was a bit smaller than my old cover, so if you are buying a plate cover, make sure to get the right size.If anything changes, then I'll update this review.

Just a short review to emulate the positive things others have said. The packaging is exceptional and, besides being functional, makes you feel like you are getting a high dollar boutique product. As with other reviewers here, I bought this sink and another one by another brand to compare in person. The other sink was marketed as being 15 gauge but the Kraus felt heavier and was better dampened for sound. My only negative comment after my initial comparison is that the semi-zero radius corners could be finished a bit more evenly. That said, I chose to keep the Kraus over the other sink that had perfect true zero radius corners. One other small concern is that the bottom rack the Kraus sink comes with looks to be chrome plated. The finish is brighter than that of the sink but, moreover, it is not possible to tell what material is under the chrome to decide if it will rust. A matching all stainless rack would be nice. I am posting this mostly in case Kraus reads these reviews. In short, I looked at a lot of sinks and would have been willing to spend three times as much if I had found something that was clearly better made. I could not find anything better, so I bought the Kraus and saved money.

I applied this to our new car and it was extremely easy.  It's stretchy enough to follow the contour of the doors edge and not create pockets of air underneath. I cleaned the edge first with Isopropyl Alcohol first to remove oils/wax. I then applied it down the center of the door edge while pulling back the tape as I worked my way down.  Then folded the sides over by pinching it and pushing outwards to ensure no bubble existed. The roll was more then enough to do our 4dr SUV and 4DR truck.

I love flashlights, so when I saw it in my local store I just had to get it. I've had this flashlight for about 2 years now, but I paid 2x of what it costs now :(Intensity of the beam is incredible (110 lumen), this is the brightest light I had so far.Besides carrying it with me, I found a great use for it as a light for my commuter bike. I got a $2 generic rubber light holder on ebay which you can attach to handlebar and this flashlight fits nicely. My commute is short so I never had problems with 30min shutoff, and it lights my way just great be it in total darkness or twilight. Makes me feel safe.There are "better" bike lights, but they require external batter pack and cost 10x more. Why bother, for my needs I go thru just 1 set of lithium batters a year, they seem to last long.Lithium batteries are expensive (but you can use alkaline or rechargeable), true, but they are also very light and great for carrying on hikes/camping. I even took it with me on my Hawaii trip. I went into a totally dark lava tube, and there were some people there with headlights. When I turned my Energizer, it cut thru the darkness like a projector, someone event screamed "ok you win!", we all had a good laugh :)Someone here mentioned about light flickering, I never had this issue. Output is steady, and you can regulate it's intensity by holding on/off button. Also it doesn't scratch easily. I carry it with me in my bag full of junk and didn't notice any damage so far.
summary: Great light for bike and everyday use.

reviewText: The Hakko FX-888 is a great soldering station.Its perfect for for the big and small jobs.  There are tons of tips available and they are relatively cheap.The iron is comfortable in the hand (which is a huge plus) and it has a wide temp range.The cord to the iron is silicone so it should take the abuse of a working environment.The stand is very sturdy and heavy enough not to move around the bench.Same for the power supply.  Cant say enough good things about it!

This is the best multi-bit screwdriver I've found.  It provides the best selection of well constructed bit's I've found in a multi-bit tool.  The grip is good and the bits are ground correctly and are quite durable.  It means I don't have to carry a almost a dozen different items and can still get the job done.  My only "want" would be for the handle to be a bit larger.I agree with some of the other reviewers that the bits can fall out and sometimes get lost.  However to me, for $10-$12, it's worth having a tool that provides excellent service and might need to get replaced after a few years because part of it gets lost.  Also, as someone already pointed out, Klein provides a lifetime guarantee so if something actually breaks they will replace it.BTW, I feel that honest, effective reviews can take the place of first-hand experiences that are lacking in online shopping. I've always appreciated the help I've received from other reviewers and work hard to return the favor as best as I can.  I hope you found this review helpful and if there was anything you thought was lacking or unclear leave a comment and I'll do what I can to fix it.
summary: Not perfect but a great value

reviewText: I have been rebuilding my decks around my house as part of Ike recovery.  I have been reusing as much of the old wood as I could and the wood you get from lumber yards these days takes a of sorting.  With this tool, I was able to straighten as I went, saving a lot of time and return trips.  Took me a little while to figure out, but the hands off ability of this tool made it possible for me to do the entire deck without assistance.  Great time and money saver (I would think) for both pros and DIYers like me.
This set of tools do exactly what they were desighned to do. They work well and are worth the money.

Yeah, the DW718 has all the extra little bells and whistles, but I'd rather keep that extra couple hundred bucks in my pocket... this is a great miter saw.  Amazon should put some extra tape around it though when they ship it.  When mine arrived the bottom was opened up, luckily everything was still there and the saw was in excellent condition.

No more contortionist moves to turn on a lamp, etc. This little button does the job! You just plug your lamp or whatever into the receiver, and it is ready to go! You can even plug a strip of plugs into it to trigger several items at the same time. Everyone should have several!
Didn't think this thing would put a sharp edge on my knives but it did a great job for what it is intend for.

I also got theZiotek 18-Inch Flat Power Strip Liberator (R) Cable, SingleThese are nice because the swivel back and forth.. so if you need the cable to go LEFT you can do so, where their other flat power strip liberator puts the cable to the RIGHT...Overall I Wish these were not as expensive but condering they swivel that's why they are more expensive..Love these!-Nigel

What a fine knife!This folding/locking blade knife by Coast is, bar none, the sharpest blade you'll ever encounter anywhere. The size makes it nice for the pocket of the average pair of jeans. There is not the slightest blade wobble, (no matter how hard you try), and it feels great in your hand.This would make a great gift for any fisherman or small game hunter. It would be really easy to clean and rust is not going to be an issue.My highest recommendation!

I installed this onto my kids shower in their bathroom.  They use it all the time.  I tried it a couple of times. It has a larger than normal face, which I like.  We have a shower head with an even larger face... that one I love!  This Moen produces some pretty good pressure and feels nice on the back, shoulders, and head.  Definitely does a good job rinsing one off.  Nice build quality. For the price, I say you pretty much can't go wrong with this.  Solid FIVE OUT OF FIVE STARS!
summary: I tried it, my kids USE it... a nice shower head!

reviewText: I was looking for a replacement cat's paw after my Exhumer was showing some signs of serious abuse and rust.  I decided to go with this particular cat's paw after hearing some good things about the company and was even told by some people that it was the 2nd best cat's paw out there (Stiletto being the best, supposedly).  Well... I couldn't afford a Stiletto so I decided to give this guy a try.My use is mostly rough carpentry, including framing, trusses, and decking.  I'm mostly pulling 8d and 12d (a few 16d) nails, and the spacing on the two ends seems to be perfect for that.  I like how it grabs the nails but it lacks slightly in weight (I'd actually prefer it to be a little heavier) and it doesn't have a punch to dent the wood around the nails for a cleaner removal.  The punch (found on the Exhumer and the Stiletto) is only a minor flaw since I don't get bonus points for making the wood pretty in my uses.Overall, I'd rate this about equal to my Exhumer.  If they had babies and made a "Sharumer" (sounds German?), that would be a heck of a cat's paw.  Either way, I switch between this cat's paw and my Exhumer depending on what kind of mood I am in or whether I had a big lunch.Another benefit of this cat's paw is the finishing.  I've abused this cat's paw quite a bit already and the paint still hasn't chipped.  Once the paint starts chipping and I get some work in the rain, I'll let y'all know how it holds up.Pros:- Good grabbing skills- Lightweight- Nice finish and paintCons:- A little too lightweight for my likings- I wouldn't mind it being maybe 3/4" longer, maybe- Nail punch to put dents around nails for clean removal
cheap, burns out quick - probably should get the better kind - not worth the hassle of changing it every week
It's hard to tell this apart from the much more expensive Phillips bulb. I've only been using it for a month, though, so long term durability is still a question.

Got this and used Bostitch FLN-200 2-Inch Flooring L-Nails in it.This Nailer worked as advertised, just make sure to oil it like everyone says.Definately recommend this to anyone that has to do a floor any larger than a standard bedroom.And also, if you plan on doing more floors in the future why rent when you can buy this for such a great price and a great product.
Freud makes great blades, period. Cuts hardwood like butter.  Highly recommend.  Need nine more words to submit so...... buy them.
All I can say is amazing! Puts out a ton of light and looks just an incandescent bulb. Without a doubt, I will be buying more!

I've been redecorating my entire house and this involves painting with a great deal of edging (cutting in) around woodwork, ceilings and walls, etc.I have personally found that I don't like the little edging tools you see with rollers or little wheels on them. They seem to load up with paint when you have a lot to edge. On the other hand they are much faster than a brush.If you have a steady hand, however, the Purdy angled brushes, especially the Nylox ones (which are 100% Nylon, rather than Nylon & Polyester), are excellent for edging/cutting in, in this amateur's opinion.This particular brush, at 1-inch width, is pretty small, but they make larger ones.
summary: Very good detail brush for "cutting in" etc.

reviewText: The probe arrived on schedule as promised and was just as described. The sensitivity to active AC voltage is good and even work on adapters. One problem is to watch for bad batteries, the pair that cam with the probe leaked after a couple on months. I was able to clean up the contacts and it worked again.

I've had various motion sensor lights and this is the one that has outlasted them all.  I have put this outside on the back patio and put other motion sensor lights in my garage.  I've been through about a half dozen of the ones in the garage while this has been on my patio.  I don't know what happens to the other kinds, I've had ones that cost as much as this one, and cheaper ones, and they all are lucky to last a year but this one.  And as the description says it doesn't come on when it rains, or leaves blowing, or anything like that as others can.  I don't know why this one is so dependable, and lasts so long, but I'll swear by it.  I just bought another brand cheap motion sensor light for the garage today sinceI couldn't find this one at two different big box stores, so it looks like I'll have to buy it at Amazon and put it in the garage.

Mansfield toilet components are easy to maintain because of availability of products like this.  Don't let a plumber talk you into replacing your mansfield fill valve or ball valve.  Typically either can be rebuilt within 5 minutes.

This works much better than our old single light finder.  The only thing is this seems to have a shallower range than the our other one.  If you're just going through normal drywall it should be no problem.

This set came on time and packaging was good. There were some rust areas on a few of the shims; however, no issues with performance. A little scrubbing with a brass brush and mineral spirits did the job. For the price you can't match this shim set. Now my joints are a tight fit.
Planned on wearing these on the plane but decided not to given the tips sticking out of my ears.  In my opinion these would be great for musicians but are not ideal for travel.

I've owned a couple other joiners, porter cable and dewalt. I bought them for the lower price. The Lamello is by far a better tool! The stability and quality construction is worth the extra cost. The pockets are consistent and line up better then cheaper joiners. I highly recommend this tool!
summary: Lamello makes the Best joiner available!

reviewText: Seems like the key component of a drill is how heavy is it and how well does it do the job. I must admit one of my favorite drills is an inexpensive lightweight Makita. The problem is that the drill bit doesn't really get grabbed well enough so the bit falls out. That is always a nuisance, but when you are up on a ladder it is more than that. My Milwaukee stopped that problem with carbide serrated teeth but it weighs a ton. Then along came this Bosch DDH181-01 and is a nice blend of all of that. It is lighter than the Milwaukee but even stronger.Fat pack high capacity batteries outperform standard lithium ions in the all important run time. Nothing like having to come down off of a ladder in order to have to change batteries.Clutch is so effective it is almost overkill. I expect a saw brake to stop a whirling blade but this Bosch DDH181-01 has the most aggressive clutch system I have ever seen. My Milwaukee brakes way better than my cheapy Makita but nothing like this Bosch. I guess if you need to do some rapid fire changing of bits repeatedly the instant stop of the rotating drill is nice.I am assuming that since this drill is selling for a little more in price than the Makita combo pack with a separate driver that the internals are built to last. I can see through the side vent window that the windings are solid copper unlike some of the cheaper drills using lesser metals. It's a tough drill which should provide years of regular use.The whole weight, power, comfort, convenience thing is moving in the right direction with this drill. It even comes with a smaller battery that shaves some weight off of the overall tool weight, and also includes a larger battery where power and longevity are of the utmost concern.The chuck may be aluminum on the outside to keep the weight down but the teeth internally are heavy steel and have a serrated double lip on them to keep drill bits in place. My Makita 6228D is a light weight drill but the teeth are smooth steel and lose grip way too easily causing the bit to drop out.Charging advantages with this Bosch have also come a long way with only a 30 minute recharge time. That alone is worth the price of admission. The batteries come with a 2 year protection plan with free replacements if they fail. That is more generous than the one year that comes with the Makita combo pack.The built in LED light is great for when you are working in dark quarters, or are outside finishing up a job right when the sun sets and you need just that little bit of extra light to finish up without dragging out the portable light setup.Another convenience item built in is the battery comes with a small on button on its heel so with a touch it illuminates one of three lights to tell you how much charge/capacity the battery has left. With the generous non-memory of a lithium ion battery that adds up to being able to take a partially charged battery and place it back in the charger and not have to worry about shortening the useable duration of the battery. So if you click the button and only see a single light, feel free to pop that one in the charger while you work with the fully charged one. With such a long battery life, and short recharge time you can easily get through the day without running short.This Bosch is the perfect blend of precision weight strength and function. Why do I say that? Because you can feather the trigger on this drill and it will move at a pace of one revolution per minute if you want (ok that is a little bit of an exaggeration but it moves so slow it is almost barely moving) so it you are setting a delicate screw you have that incredibly fine level of control, or you can set it at high speed and stand on the drill to get the brute force jobs done. So it is a precision piece of equipment. It is not usual to find this kind of strength and fine precision in one package.
summary: Brute Force, Extra Long Battery Life, Moderate Weight, Long Guarantee

reviewText: Nice product idea but hard to use.You must use with 5mm pencil.Rule is tippy and hard to control - so hard to get a straight line.For the money there are better options
summary: Nice idea, does not perform well

reviewText: I bought a couple pair of these and ended up giving them away and replacing with "3M Peltor H10A Optime 105 Earmuffs"  These Pyramex ones work ok at reducing sound, but they have a relatively poor fit compared to the 3M.  Also, everytime you take them off they will lose their height setting.  This makes it so that you have to tug them down onto your head and then give them a the standard wiggle to settle them in place each time you wear them.  Also, when you take them off they collapse up into a ball.. the top of the ear muffs will slide up and contact the bottom of the headband.  They are a bit bothersome to have to swing them down into the normal position each time you want to wear them.  I'd go with the 3M H10A unless you really need ones that collapse up into a ball.

Since I've never been able to find this size in the stores, I purchase my filters online and usually from Amazon. For some reason most filters are actually slightly smaller than the stated size. This in my unit there is a lot of play side to side with these filters. I like being able to purchase actual size filters here for a good price. Finally I have a filter that slides in without all that loosey goosey play on the sides and unfiltered air slipping through on the sides.The filter seems to do a good job filtering dust out of the air.

After reading the stellar reviews I guess I expected too much. These are good gloves but I find they're not thick enough for tough work requiring protection for the hands and they're not quite sensitive enough for delicate chores like seed or start planting.

..And have been meaning to review it.The drill itself, as with any Dewalt tool I have bought, has been entirely satisfactory.There are two weak points, though.Replacement batteries are very expensive.  The two small capacity batteries supplied with the drill are like those half-filled cartridges you get when you buy a laser printed.  After about a hundred charge/discharge cycles, their capacity diminishes to the point where their performance is not much better than an old NiCad.The chuck deserves special attention.  Sometimes chucks with a large capacity range do so at the cost of mechanical advantage and gripping force.People who work with styrofoam, cork, and balsa wood will appreciate the torque-limiting "Feature" of this worthless chuck.People who do metalworking and drilling and tapping are in for special torment.Sometimes the drill FALLS out. I see, at the hardware store, drill sets sold by Dewalt that have three flats on the shank at 120, and know why they supplied them.To work with these chucks!I regret throwing my old drill away..the chuck worked, and I could have swapped it.Otherwise the drill is excellent.  Maybe I'll put a keyed chuck on it.One star demerit for the chuck, for which I have run our of cuss words and even languages, when I talk to it. Loudly.

UPDATE to review below, Sept. 1, 2012I looked online for "direct replacement" batteries for these scissors. No luck there, certainly not from Black and Decker. I learned that the three 1.2 volt battery cells inside, which are soldered together with tabs to make a larger 3.6 volt battery pack, are called "Sub C". Further that they are a smaller size of "Sub C", so if you go looking for them, make sure you compare the originals with what you are going to buy. These are a little shorter than another kind of "Sub C".I ended up at a local store called Batteries Plus, where they carry the correct size Sub C (sold separately, not connected). Cost for 3 batteries was $14.50. (online prices for Sub C batteries are a bit lower but shipping makes total cost higher). Yes, I could have bought a new scissors for a little more than that, but I truly hate throwing good items away just because the manufacturer does not support them after the sale with something as simple as replacing a battery pack. I bought 3 batteries and merely taped them together. The solder tabs connecting between batteries on the original pack are not necessary, I found...I just put batteries end to end (like in a flashlight) and taped them together to form a pack. The original pack has a cardboard tube around it you can re-use to also help hold things together. I did remove the spade connectors from each end of the old pack and re-soldered them to my new pack. These tabs are needed to connect to the spade connectors/wiring inside the scissors. Total repair time after I had the batteries in hand: 30 minutes.I know this is more work than some people are going to want to do when their batteries die, but my scissors are now working again. Plus, I taught one of my kids how to solder. And how to fix something rather than throwing it in the trash when it stops working. In the future I'll weigh carefully any purchases of battery-powered devices from Black and Decker.Original review below:I've had these scissors for about 2.5 years, used maybe once every 2 weeks to cut paper in an office (not overused, in other words, but used regularly). It cuts well when working, but recently it stopped taking a charge. I looked at Black & Decker's website, and all parts for this scissor (and 2 similar models) are listed as "unavailable". There is no listing at all for a new battery at B&D;'s site under this product. Perhaps it's buried in their user-unfriendly website somewhere else but as there is no part number on the battery, nor even a description of what kind of battery it is (other than "Type 1 3.6V" on the outside of the scissors), it's kind of hard to search. Other reviewers here have stated the battery costs more than a new scissor (but not where they got a battery). Perhaps that's life in America today but I find it distressing that I'm supposed to just throw these scissors away and buy a new pair because B&D; cannot make the battery available nor sell it for less than the cost of a new scissors. I would suggest looking at other brands for your cutting needs which is what I'll likely be doing. If I do find a battery, I will update this review with cost and details.
summary: Dislike "disposable" products (update, I found batteries, but...)

reviewText: Ordered a spool of this last month and have been working with it since then. Great Solder for the price.

Summary:It works fine, but doesn't live up to its sales hype. If you want an assisted-opening knife in the low 20s for dollars this is your knife.  If you are looking for a professional tactical knife suitable for police, fire, rescue, etc. professions, you'll need to spend more to get more.The parts:* 5Cr15Mov stainless steel.  Decent for the money.* 3" hollow ground blade with drop-point with swage on top; it has a bit of poor jimping spine place where your thumb isn't.  It has an attractive satin (bead blasted?) finish.* Out of the box, it was as dull as cub-scout pocket knife -- wouldn't cut much of anything without using a sawing motion.* Nice, grippy but not grabby fiber reinforced nylon handles.  These are the best element of the knife.* It uses a liner-lock to hold the blade open which worked well.* The clip is also satin finish; very sturdy and shaped so that the knife rides deep in the pocket as I prefer.* The assisted opening is powered by a leaf spring and initiated by opening the knife using as with a conventional thumb stud.  In the resting position, the leaf spring is flexed so as to keep the knife closed.  With sufficient force on the thumb stud, the spring force is overcome and then reversed so that the blade is driven explosively over the first 60 degrees or so of opening, depending on momentum to carry it the remaining 120 degrees to the fully open position* There is also a patented "Double-Lock" capability that I think perhaps has some value in ensuring the blade does not spring open inadvertently (or close) inadvertently but which I don't believe is necessary in light of the active tension holding the blade in the closed position and the liner-lock which retains it in the open position.The sum:of the parts* The weight is right, while the size is a bit small for me, but I have large hands.* The blade opening is difficult at first, but gets easier with practice.  But practice does not change that it takes considerable pressure on the thumb stud to overcome the initial resistance (closing force) of the leaf spring.  Some reviewers indicate they simply can't open this knife one handed - I can believe it.* I feel like the explosive initial blade opening after which it coasts into the fully open position is more dangerous and less certain than a design which opens with less force but acting over the entire distance.* If your hands are strong but not large and if you want to own an assisted-opening blade without spending too much, consider the CX311.  If you are a professional looking for a professional-grade assisted opening knife, plan on paying 3 to 4 times this amount and getting a blade 3 or 4 times better suited to the task.
We just bought these in May of 2014 so not sure yet about longevity but the lights themselves are nice looking and functional.
These staples were exactly as advertised and what we needed to do the job we had to do.  Great box for storage.
A great precision tool. Not like those cheap Chinese hand drills with two jaws. I recommend this tool for fine detail hole drilling.
