reviewText: Almost every light fixture in the house is on a dimmer, interior and exterior.  After purchasing about 20 total of these every single one buzzes while on a dimmer.  Those on a conventional switch do not buzz.  Yes the dimmers are LED compatible.  You should hear my new dining room, the chandelier has 9 Cree bulbs, it sounds like I'm next to a transformer.  buzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzIt's too bad, the price of these has come down and they give off a pretty good Kalvin.  Time to look into the Philliips bulbs that "do not buzz" as mentioned in other reviews.UPDATE: I just installed (3) Phillips soft white led bulbs on a dimable fixture. No buzz!!  I like the color better than the Cree as well.

Does a very nice job. Easy to set up, easy to use. Would give 5 stars except for one annoying little thing....... You cannot fold up the outfeed tray with the dust collection hood attached. This makes it a little challenging to store when you are short on space.
These are great, fit my impact driver well, have a solid hold with the ball detent, and are a great addition to the tool chest.

We have LEDs in all of our home's lights except inside the stove and the refrigerator. We've had all LEDs, except those two spots, for seven years. Over that time the LED bulbs have vastly improved. This CREE bulb is a good LED light, a lot better than some but there are problems:One of the bulbs we received was defective. Yes, defects happen but they seem to happen a lot more with the LEDs. The CREE is no exception.The CREE bulb does not work in our refrigerator. There is a regular incandescent bulb in there. It appears that the base of the CREE LED bulb widens too much after it gets past the metal portion such that the plastic part of the bulb blocks the bulb from being screwed enough into the socket to make electrical contact. That's a bad design on CREEs part. The bulbs should just work.Since it is plastic I can't use it in the oven, of course, but I had hoped to use it in the fridge.

I put these on our stairs and entryway as we do not have an outlet and they are perfect.  I am going to be ordering more for other areas of the house so our daughter can maneuver around at night and not be scared.

These have been a great disappointment!!  My TV remote of all things can set it off in the den.  Near the bedroom the florescent light sets that one off, lol.  Not funny at 3:00am let me tell u.  I kept the one in the Den after repositioning  it further from the light source the remote still very rarely sets it off but oh well.  The bedroom one we gave away with a warning I hope - but no it had to go!  Bought a simple replacement and intend to do the same from now on.

This product works as advertised. It's easy to install and reliable. The motion detection sensitivity setup is a nice touch.It's not for everyone though.1. It requires 4 AA batteries. It's a lot of power and expense for a little LED. Batteries will last about 2 months.2. It's not that bright. It provides good lighting on about 2 feet diameter area.
only on the stairs for 2 days - but the sensitivity to motion is fantastic.  the 4 stars is because brightness is blinding.  If you have on the stairs above you, even from the side, it is too bright.

This works well and the 140 lumens i great.  I would rather spend the money to get a smaller and brighter C4 LED flashlight and pack away my old mag light but this gives it new life.  still a big, bulky light but now a bit brighter.  Not a bad way to give your mag light a new lease on life.

Using a power drill to drive screws with just a tip is not pleasant. Using the DeWalt magnetic drive guide not only holds the tip securely, but the sliding grip holds the screw steady as you apply pressure. Getting two sizes is nice, too. Oh, great price and awesome Amazon service is a bonus!

Love this thing.I just finished installing it with my Hunter Barrington model 28795 fan.  I was initially worried that this was a solid state controller and that it wouldn't work with the fan since the manual for the fan says not to use it with a solid state controller and to buy a Hunter brand controller.  Well, I would have just bought the Hunter controller if their controllers didn't look awful and have only basic features.  Instead, I bought this controller and called the Lutron service number on the back.  Within a few minutes, I was talking with a well informed support rep who told me not to worry and that the control was a capacitive type.  It would work with the fan, he said.  I took his word for it and opened the package and hooked it up.  BOOM!  It worked right away without issue.I know it's just a fan controller, but it is in my family room and it really makes the house look more up-to-date being there.  There's some cool functions with a lights-out timer and restoring to the last dimness/fan speed with a single press.  Double tap to go full speed no matter what state it's in.In my case, there was plenty of room in the canopy for the remote, I didn't have to fight it much at all to install.If I had one suggestion for improvement it would be that they should make the led's not flicker as much (hard to notice for most, probably).  But it's not very bothersome so don't let that turn you off of this great fan controller.
summary: NOT a solid state controller - instead it's capacitive.  Great controller.

reviewText: The Tap-n-Flush system is an extremely well designed and effective product, which helps you to reduce water usage in your toilet.  Over time, the savings you realize should pay for the cost of the product.There are times when you don’t need to use a full tank of water to flush the toilet.  On those occasions, Tap-n-Flush can reduce the amount of water that is used, by using an electronically controlled weight, to shorten the normal flushing cycle.  The option to use the full amount of water always remains available, but can also be adjusted to save water.Since I have old lift rod type toilets, when I was contacted about reviewing the Tap-n-Flush converter, I was intrigued at the possibility of being able to reduce water consumption, but was unsure if the device would work on such “ancient” technology.  Jeff at Tap-n-Flush assured me that it would, so I decided to try it out.With a minimal knowledge of plumbing, I was a little intimidated when I first opened the box, as the tray inside was filled with numerous plastic and metal parts.  There was actually no cause for concern however, because only a few of the parts were actually required to successfully retrofit my particular type of toilet.  Amazingly, the conversion process took only about 10 minutes, and required no tools!I had no idea that there were so many different kinds of plumbing systems for toilets.  The Tap-n-Flush is intended as a “universal” product, compatible with wide variety of these systems, which is why it comes with so many parts.  Fortunately the system comes with a great set of comprehensive and well written instructions.  There are a couple of booklets covering the various types of toilets, with extremely helpful diagrams that show what needs to be done.The Tap-n-Flush system consists of three basic components, a control unit, a weight, and a unit that releases a chain attached to the weight.  For a lift rod type toilet, the weight is attached to the lift rod, and placed near the rubber plug at the bottom of the tank.  The weight controller hangs on the inside of the tank, above the plug.  A ribbon wire runs between the weight controller, and the battery powered control unit, which is supposed to be placed on the top cover of the toilet tank.  Since I have cleaning stuff on the top of my toilet, I used double stick tape, and attached the controller to the wall.The system has to be “calibrated” to your particular type of toilet, by conducting a series of test flushes.  To get the best results, I found that I needed to add an extra metal disc to the weight, but after that, I was pretty much set.  Pressing the top cover of the control unit activates the system, and results in a reduction of water usage of about 30% per flush.  Since the tank in my toilet holds a lot more water than more modern toilets, the savings using Tap-n-Flush are quite significant.Other reviewers can speak to how well the device works with other types of toilet systems, but if you have an old lift rod type toilet, the Tap-n-Flush system definitely works.  The instructions are clear, and comprehensive, and even with minimal skills, installation should be simple.I have a few suggestions for improving this product.  Since the space on top the toilet may not be always available, there should be other provisions for mounting the control unit.  Besides the double stick tape method I used, mounting ears for screwing the unit the wall, would be one solution.  In some cases, the ribbon wire may not be long enough, so the manufacturer might want to lengthen it a bit.With an ability to be installed on a variety of toilet systems, nearly everyone can realize a reduction in water usage, by properly installing the Tap-n-Flush system.  The device is easily removable if you do change your residence, so both renters as well as home owners, should seriously consider this product.  It occasionally drops in price, which would be a good time to get one.
summary: you owe it to yourself to check out this fantastic product…

reviewText: OK, I had high hopes for this light.  First off, the positive:1.  Very bright.Now the negative:1.  Flimsy construction.2.  Solar panel offers very little adjustment.  You can adjust the tilt, but not tilt and angle.  So if you are limited on your mounting location, then you have to just do the best you can.3.  Adjustment of the light is also very poor.I installed this light and it worked great, for about 3 days.  Then it stopped working and I thought maybe it just needs to charge.  Well, two months later and the light will come on literally for 1/2 second in a flash.  No amount of adjustment will fix it.  Unfortunately, I waited 17 days too long to return to amazon.com and the return period just ended.  So I just wasted good money on a bad light.
summary: This light is a hunk of junk

For some reason I thought a standard battery would work. My bad! Now I've got to wait to use this. I hope it is as bright as the UltraFire CREE XML T6, I really like that flashlight!I only gave this a 4 star rating because I haven't seen how bright it is. IF it is 1000 lumens bright it deserves the 5 star rating possible. Very robust construction and great compact pocket sized unit.

reviewText: I live just outside of city limits and the wild pigs had been destroying my yard. I put two, one in house and one in out building. After the first night of use, No more hogs

I do find it best to strike the punch several times and gradually punch the hole. I used these punches to cut holes in canvas and neoprene rubber.
This is a good price for these screwdriver bits, and I like having the complete set in a handy and sturdy case.

I'll start with a brief background of this saw (DWE7491RS) and it's fellow mates, the 7480 and the 7490X.  These units appear to be late 2013 upgraded replacements to the previously successful 744 and 745 series saws.  Upgraded specifications from the previous series are a 4,800RPM no-load blade speed (from 3,850RPM), a larger dust port (2-1/2" vs 2-1/4"), slightly heavier weight and for the 7491, an improved rolling stand system with integrated tool & safety accessory storage.  Most interesting to me, the 7490X and 7491RS series feature an improved fence system that has pushed the industry limits of contractor saws past the 24-1/2 inch barrier.Aside from the aforementioned upgrades, most of the other specifications (like cut depths) are identical to the previous 744/745 series.  The least expensive model, the 7480, is no longer crippled like the 745 was...even the least model has a 24-1/2" fence to rip sheet goods in half.  Both the 7490X and 7491RS can accept dado blades, but Dewalt does now say on the 7480 that dado blades are "not recommended."  The new series also seem to carry a heftier price tag at the moment, but the money does seem put to good use.  The trusted rack & pinion fence adjustment is still present, so your fence will remain true through heavy use.The new models seem to have similar differentiation as the previous series and the deciding factors are fairly straight forward based on your needs.  If you want a basic 24-1/2 rip capacity saw with no stand, the 7480 is your choice.  If you want to improve your rip capacity to 28-1/2" and have a stationary (but still portable) integrated stand, the 7490X is your choice.  If you want maximum portability in a rolling stand, along with an impressive 32-1/2" rip capacity and a bonus fully integrated system storage, you go with the 7491RS series.Some would say that 24-1/2" rip capacity is all that's needed.  It's true that you can rip the short side of a 48" sheet good, but it means you would have a fair amount of material hanging off to the left side of the blade.  You can't do it alone, that's pretty well a fact.  The improved fence system solves just this problem and provides adequate material support where it's needed.  It features two positions for the fence, which can be moved outward to accommodate the large 32-1/2" capacity.  The measurement scale accommodates both fence positions with one starting at 0" and the other at 8" and out of the box, it was pretty close to accurate.  (See usage update below.)  I have noticed that the fence material support bracket is less strong at the maximum distance, but it doesn't seem to make a major difference since it's really only for basic material support.I never used the previous model of rolling stand (744 series), but comparatively I think this one is a bit easier to manipulate from what I saw of YouTube videos.  Although the saw and stand are fairly heavy assembled, getting it from storage/rolling position to operating position (and back) is a safe, easy and quick process.  It might present a challenge for shorter/lighter folks, but it's easy for me with average height and weight.  Once in place, the saw is sturdy as a rock...no problems with movement and it's not side heavy in any particular direction.  I also liked that the handle can be positioned in two ways...compact (for tighter storage) and easy-to-carry.Assembly was really quite simple and the instructions/diagrams are clear, it took maybe an hour to assemble and a bit after that to learn the major adjustments and perform blade checks so I could get started.  All your common adjustments are found within easy reach and I found that calibration adjustments I wanted to make were quite easy to perform.  It's great to have all your safety gear completely integrated into the stand, everything has a place and it's less like for safety gear to be misplaced or unused entirely.  The saw features a no-fail recessed power-on button with a large stop that could be easily kneed or kicked in an emergent situation.  There's basically no way this thing could inadvertently turn on, but as always, it's best to practice power-off safety when working directly with the blade.  The riving knife accessories are super easy to install or remove, which means I'll probably end up using it in most cases!My biggest gripes at the moment are due to a lack of accessories.  I've read that the older series dado inserts aren't a 100% match and fit fairly loose in these new saws.  Sure enough, Dewalt doesn't list any accessories available for this particular saw as of this moment...so that's probably not a preferred path right now.  (No infeed or side supports either.)  I'm betting this will change at some point in the future.  You can use a generic adjustable roller stand (or custom built outfeed table) and DIY dado/zero clearance plates in the mean time.  I thought about taking away a star for that, but with workable solutions right now, it's not a big deal for me.  Also, the provided miter guage is not really practical, but anyone who's semi-serious in outfitting their saw is going to build/buy a decent crosscut sled and a miter sled anyway.Overall, with the increased power and larger fence system, this particular unit is starting to approach cabinet saw capabilities.  It's by no means an absolute replacement, but it's certainly more capable than the predecessors and competitors offerings.  If you're like me and you want the capacity of a cabinet saw, but the need for storage/portability triumphs above all...then this unit is definitely something you should look at.  Yes, it commands the highest price of common portable contractor saws on the market right now, but it's money well spent if the increased fence capacity and refined portability is worth it to you.  As they say...buy once, cry once.I'll update this review when I've had a chance to run various materials through it, but initial performance is great.  I tried both soft woods (pine, fir) without any incident and I could definitely notice the power upgrade for the hard woods (tried walnut, cherry & QS oak so far).  I got nice, clean cuts and quick measurements across the fence were accurate enough for me.  As with pretty much any saw, the provided blade is sufficient for rough cuts...but you'll want 60/80 tooth 10" blades for any fine work.  I have a couple cabinets to mill down and build in the immediate future, so I'll certainly be putting this saw through a workout of it's advertised capabilities over the next few weeks.Usage update:  I've used the saw for quite a few hours now, so I have a pretty good feel for the shortcomings and limitations.* It cuts everything I've thrown at it like butter.  I found some 8/4 cherry to try and although it slowed her down more than I'd seen, she chewed through it just fine.  I think it could easily take on a 12/4 piece with enough time and patience.  I am also loving that large fence and use it more often than I anticipated already...it's been awesome to easily cut larger panels easily.  I can only comfortably cut 4'x4' panels on my own, but I did do a 6'x4' panel in two cuts without too much trouble.  (One rough, one final.)  Anything larger (and especially full sheet cross cuts) and you'll need help or a decent infeed/outfeed system.  Do be aware that when you push this saw hard, it will draw more than 15 amps and can trip fuses/breakers that are rated at that level or less.  I use a vacuum switch with a 15 amp fuse and it trips when I push it hard...if I didn't have that, my breaker would likely blow.* I mentioned in my original review that the table top was "flat as could be."  Well, according to my dial gauge and straight edge, there is a slope of about .015" across the width of the table.  This doesn't have any significant impacts as far as I can tell, as long as your blade is 90 degrees (or the desired bevel setting) to that slope.  Also, I'm not thrilled with the tabletop or coating.  Upon building my panel and cross cut sleds, I found it would fairly easily rub off with even the lightest friction.  (It didn't take long at all to get that "used" look.)  It's also not at all ferrous, so no attaching magnets...probably to save weight since actual metal is, umm, heavy.  Plan on using using clamps if needed to secure things, both regular and miter slot as desired.* Upon a full tune-up/settings check, my fence distance gauge was off by over .015".  No big deal and an easy fix, but I was having trouble getting even close to precision for some cuts off the gauge.  Also, my fence was off parallel to the miter slot at position 2 by almost .010" front to back.  Probably not enough to cause problems with most cuts or rough work, but too much for my preferences.  Also an easy fix, but it did take some fussing to get it "just right."  The arbor and fence at position 1 were close enough to perfect.  It was a little irritating to have to tweak a new saw into perfection, but it wasn't too difficult and is probably due to the primary market for this saw being rough work, not cabinet grade.  If you're going for precision, you may need to adjust from the factory.  I recommend a quality try or combo square, a shop made fence measuring jig (or an A-Line It jig) and a digital or analog caliper for determining error rates.* I found that my 60+ tooth fine blades require me to remove the dust shroud in order to remove the blade.  An inconvenience and it adds about 1 minute to the process, but not that big of a deal unless you're constantly changing blades.* Total dust collection is a mystery until Dewalt does something.  At least if you rely on a Shop Vac and 2-1/2" hose.  The 2-1/2" port is solid, no problem, and catches most dust.  But, a fair bit of dust kicks up as usual...which is why they designed the riving knife with integrated dust chute.  Awesome option, but absolutely ludicrous to plumb for at this time, making the accessory virtually worthless.  There is no 2-1/2"x1-1/4" Y adapter out there and I'm not going to use 5+ fittings, convert to 4" and add a bunch of extra hose to do it.  I find the normal fallout with the regular knife preferable to shooting it six feet across the room.* Some quick things that are hard to find about this saw. It takes up to a 8" sized dado blade, up to 13/16" in width.  (I haven't used a 6" dado, but an 8" worked fine...I can imagine a 6" would work with less max depth.)  The working table top height is 36-3/8".  Maximum storage height is about 44-3/4" with the handle in compact position or just over 48" in easy-carry position.  There's a lot of mis-info in the Q&A; here and even from the manufacturer, these measurements are from my actual 7491RS saw.  Feel free to comment if you want other fairly precise measurements.  Accessories for this saw will start rolling out Q1 of 2014, with a dado plate being the first anticipated accessory to roll out from Dewalt.Other than those things, I still think it's an excellent saw.  Maybe 4.5 stars would be my actual rating due to the from-the-factory adjustments I had to make and my disappointment with the table top.  Other than that, it's been comfortable to use and work with and is giving me great results and perfect joints.  I'll update if anything else comes up.
summary: Pushes The Limits For Portability And Flexibility

reviewText: I bought these while using polyurethane on a floor in the middle of winter with the charcoal filters when I couldn't get much ventilation . Never even got a wiff of toxic fumes. My only warning would be that because you don't smell the fumes can keep you unaware of the lack of oxygen in the room. So be careful and don't work long in a closed space. In fact tell your customer that you will come back in spring when you can open windows. Comfortable to wear and easy to use.
Plug one end in outlet attach other to led strips and you have UCL under cabinet lights.  Low profile so cannot see transformer while standing

This didn't go as far as it should have. I didn't have any issue with dead cans, but it just didn't cover like other paint like it. It also should deb called gloss safety orange. I was expecting a more flat true orange, but it is a glossy safety cone color.

The dimensions were accurate in the description. The bag works just as intended, and holds a lot. It holds all the first responder kit that I assembled and stuffed into it. The pockets hold large bandages well, and the other pocket holds loose items. Seems well made, and can probably hold tools, or something heavyweight very well.

Saw both the Bosch and this saw in the store and compared them.  If the Bosch had this Dewalt's fence system, I probably would have bought it just to get the dado blade compatibility (even if I never used it).  But, it didn't and this saw is also really nice and I have never looked back.The fence is by far the best selling point.  It's so easy to adjust and has an easy to read ruler.  Put a wood floor in three rooms of my housing using this plus my miter saw.  Still holding up strong and cuts very cleanly, even with very hard hardwood (acacia a.k.a. asian walnut).

"Use the included software to create times events for your X10 units!"The above statement is no longer true.I've been told X10 is going out of business and the only source listed above "Home Control Plus" says "Software is NOT included just the hardware".  If you're making a new setup you would need the software.This would be to replace an 'existing CM15A' that has the needed software.  Not for the non-techie family.I did NOT purchase this item because of no software.

I really like the variety of pieces that this set offers, especially when compared to sets by other manufacturers. As another reviewer mentioned, it would be nice to have more straight pegs and fewer hooked ones.I also wish that Neiko made parts to conveniently lock down their pegs. The Crawford-Leighton(sp?) peg lock set does not work with this set of Neiko pegs. I would go with the Crawford-Leighton peg set to solve this but their set isn't nearly as complete as this Neiko set.

I received my first order sold by Art Display Systems and received the a small box with the bumpers and additional picture hanging bumpers and hardware. I ran through the bumpers quickly putting them on all of our cabinets and pictures. When I reorder the same product which was sold by West Florida Components I only received a sheet of bumpers!  The set sold by Art Display Systems adhered great. I will have to use the news ones from West Florida Components to determine if there is a difference in quality. I liked the small box and 4 - 6x6 sheets bumpers supplied by Art Display Systems and the fact that I also received the picture hanging hardware and additional bumpers for the same cost.

LED flashlights and lighting in general are now in the revolutionary phase and this flashlight is right up there. The MFGs are moulding small parabolic reflectors that perfectly fit the LED chips and when you put a lot of them together - hold on to your hat. This flashlight is nothing more or less than a superbly machined barrel that holds three lithium batteries and what is it? 12 LEDs. OK, give me 24.You want lots of light in a small package? Here it is. No magic, just brute LED horsepower.By the way, shine this baby in the eyes of an intruder and he will not be seeing anything clearly for enough time that you can drag out your shotgun and do what needs to be done. Put it on strobe and don't look at the light yourself. Unless he is a zombie, he'll be on the way out, forgetting about your big screen and laptop.

I got these to try to work over my or my wives presciption glasses.  Work better with mine than my wifes.  They are comfortable enough, but just was not designed for what I wanted to use them for.  Would be excellent for contacts

reviewText: Would be 5 stars if it was available in different sizes. As it is, it's a little big for my wrist but a little small for an ankle, so it's ended up looped around a purse handle and I'll find something else to wear on my person. Otherwise it's great.
This thing will truly climb walls and bridge distances of 12'. It is heavy, but it works well and is better in a tool belt than just hanging off of your pocket.
This is a very bright light, and gives the impression of sunlight.  Very white, not warm on the spectrum. It also last a very long time, even if you leave it on all day.

Love the Brita filter.  Use it on my kitchen sink for drinking water.  I have a well and the water is incredibly clear but just to be safe I use the Brita filter.  The filter has a small light that will blink green/yellow or red depending on how soon you need to replace it.  Very convenient!  I was a bit dismayed about the lack of recycle options however - so I contacted Brita and inquired and they said you can send them the used filters and they will recycle them - although, I wonder if their form of "recycling" is just throwing them in their dumpster since they do not mention any recycle efforts on their web site.  The ONLY downfall to this product is the lack of recycling options.

Works as advertised and has saved me a ton of time messing around with wire strippers or razor blades to get the jacket off of Cat 5. Just a couple of turns easily cuts the jacket all the way through and doesn't touch the wires. Jacket will slide right off. Perfect.

These are just what I wanted for all my creations.  I like to make things and tea light candles just are not safe to use with them.  These are great, for my lanterns, for my artistic endeavours.  They flicker like real candles, have and on/off switch, come with extra batteries. Long Lasting (Over 40 Hours), One Year Warranty.  Good customer service.
Using this as our backdoor handle, makes it easy to get in when carrying a load.  Great quality, easy installation.  Also using the matching security pad/dead bolt.  Looks really nice.

I bought three sets of these several years ago for a Dustbuster & 2 cordless screwdrivers. They are very reliable products. Although expensive, they are a better alternative than trying to keep NI-CDs charged or throwing the appliances in the recycling bin or trash can.

reviewText: This is a godsend when looking at potential offices/houses to rent. Who wants to hook up a bunch of expensive electrical equipment to an UNGROUNDED outlet? So many places seem to have this issue, this weeds them out very quickly and is easy to use. I have had this for years and it is quite durable. Buy this!
Nice American made tools.  Delivered on time. I bought many different sets and gave them as gifts to professional industrial plant repair men.  I got them for myself.  Great price.
Used to cut plastic, steel, etc.  No complaints, decent life from each one.  Would buy again.Dremel 426 Fiberglass Reinforced Cut-Off Wheels 1- 1/4" Dia., .045" Thick
this was the cheapest 6" hole saw set i saw.  dont know why anyone would give this less than 5 stars cause it does everything it is advertised to do and works well.
Not really as described. Some tools are good but for the most part it's a waste of money and not good for an adult project.

Gonna give this a 5 star, even though the compressor is a little lacking, and the provided PVC hose is next to useless.Mine came with the newer 16gauge finish nailer - the 51257 model.  I like that as the depth adjuster is much nicer (for me at least).  Loading is a little quirky, but nothing too bad.  I don't really care much for the adjustable "hanger" for the gun, it always seems like its in the way.  Jam clearing is totally easy, tool-less and a non issue.Brad nailer is the 51236, a decently nice brad nailer, that goes down to 5/8" brads of 18gauge.Compressor... its ok, quiet.  Not really all that powerful, could use something a bit more for continuous work.  Its just fine if you're installing molding or trim, cutting pieces as you go, then nailing them in.  If you're doing continuous nailing, its not really adequate.Didn't come with bump triggers.Outer box reeked of insecticide.  I'm guessing somebody's warehouse got treated before it was shipped.  I had it held at UPS since they deliver when I'm out working.  Even the UPS counter man asked me about the smell, it was that strong.I don't expect any equipment issues here.  I needed to get a brad and finish nailer.  I got the combo mainly to sell the compressor - its already sold BTW - and reduce my total cost on the nailers.  I got $150 for the compressor, so that much was accomplished, and it brought my combined nailer cost down to just over $100.  That made it a good deal, great deal even.
I bought these to light a small area to see numbers on a keypad in the dark. Tried both rechargeable and regular batteries and the light is barely bright enough to make out the keys.

If you're doing light finish work or hobby work this is an excellent tool!  The brad and finish nailers are great.  I've not had them jam at all.  The tank is just big enough to last for small projects and the cord that comes with the tool is long enough to reach even with the tank stationary.  I recommend this tool to any finish carpenter or hobbyist needing the versatility and convenience of a great air compressor.

I loved this light, the best clamp-on LED with battery I have found. But the darn light eats the batteries when turned off, yes, off. Tried the experiment three times and every morning the light drained all the batteries. We sent it back. If Jumbl can fix this, I would get one again in the same day. Much better light than the Daffodil, but battery thing was unacceptable.

As stated above, the remote appears to be of great quality but I had to return it because it wasn't compatible with my opened. Suggest you look at the Liftmaster site to get the correct application info because what's published on Amazon seems mostly incorrect for these remotes,

Hey, what can I say? I got this cordless Dremel FREE off of Craigslist because they jammed the collet with a bad bit. After prying the bit out and oiling up the collet and seeing no real damage I went on a hunt for a battery and charger for this guy.  This is the proprietary battery that you need for this cordless Dremel. I got lucky on price and also found the charger for under $20.00 so I ended up spending about $40.00 for a brand new Cordless Dremel with accessories. Thank you Amazon!

reviewText: No issues at all works great and much nicer than older model

The Bear Grylls is too heavy to be attached to keys and to keep in the pocket. Some of the tools are difficult to pull out, end up having to use a flat head screwdriver to prise out the tools. Would prefer the Leatherman PS4 compared to this.
Small little needle nose that always come in handy when you need them so I recommend them to get for your toolbox.

Ordered the Dewalt DW5204 Concrete Bits and these have been working out really well.PACKAGE:The package arrive damaged.  These come in a little plastic pouch which was ripped when the item arrived.  The bits were still in the package but just a ripped package so have to be careful now that the bits don't fall out but not a big deal.DRILL BITS:The bits have not broken and are still working like new three weeks later of constant use.  Using these to drill holes into the wall in order to put anchors to hang items.  The drill bits go in really easy without having to put a lot of pressure and have not been chipping the concrete.Not much else to say other then not a bad item for the price.  The packaging isn't to great but wasn't bought for the pretty package.

The steam cleaner works very well, heats up fast and easy to use. There is no safety feature that would have prevented someone (kids) to release hot steam while unit is heating. That is why I can only use when somebody else is available to watch the kids and make sure they are safe and well out of the way. Also, please make a note that the steam coming out of the nozzle is quite loud.Otherwise, I really like how it cleans, and it removes grime from hard to reach crevices and does not use any chemicals. I am very impressed with this unit.

reviewerName: Richard C. Drew "Anaal Nathra/Uthe vas Bethod...
reviewText: I own a bunch of electronic tape measures - collected several over the years. Most recently it's been laser instead of sonic. The inexpensive (comparatively) audio / sonic models are under $100. The laser models can cost upwards of $400 for every feature under the sun (Bluetooth and more), while models that do more than you'll probably ever need cost $150-$300. All manufacturers of laser distance measurers offer a few models - and all price the same. The lower the price, the shorter the distance and the fewer the features. Stanley offers three models - 330 feet, 165 feet and 100 feet.  These distances are in ideal conditions. Dust, bright light and even high humidity can effect this. So if you're planning on usually measuring towards the high end of a range, say 95 - 100 feet, then you should purchase the next model up - or more.  I have the 330 foot version of the Stanley and the Bosch GLR825. The Bosch goes to 800 feet.I'll compare the top Bosch model to the top Stanley model, as I own and use them both.Power: Staney uses 2 AAA batteries, the Bosch 4 AAARange: Stanley 330 feet, Bosch 800 feet (they do have models with less range)Cost: Bosch is $100 moreWeatherproofing: Stanley - claims to be weatherproffed, but there's no gasket on the battery door. There's actually a opening by the clip. Bosch, weather proofed, including a gasket on the battery door.  I don't know if the less expensive Bosch models are weatherproofed.Size: Stanley is about the size of a pack of cigarettes. Bosch is about twice the bulk (it's thicker, wider and longer) and 3x the weight.Display: Both have multi-line backlit displays, although the Bosch is about 25% largerAccuracy: Both boast 1mm accuracy over the full rangeIf you're a home-owner, carpenter, painter, carpet layer, etc. this is the ideal distance measurer - even pros will appreciate it, as long as you don't use it in really wet conditions. 330 feet is plenty for most people. Rain can effect the accuracy, so for most people this is not an issue. You can also "chain" measurements, say 200'+200'+300' and so on.One feature I like about these devices is the "advanced" math they do for you - OK, it's basic math for many of us, but it's a real time saver. Area, volume, SQFT, angles, indirect measurements, min-max and more. You could calculate paint and carpet requirements for a room with only a few button presses.All of these devices share one flaw - the person pressing the button. If the laser is at even a slight angle, the distance can change by fractions to inches. This is where the max/min comes in handy. For example, measuring from wall to wall, you want the minimum.  If the laser tilts up or down and / or side to side, the distance changes. You also may not be holding it level and perpendicular - so you purposely wiggle it a little and use the min value. Many pros will use these on a leveled tripod - there's a 1/4-20 standard tripod mounting hole.The included CD contains the 20 page owner's manual. I'd rather have a printed version. There is a really nice fold-out quick reference that fits in the included carry pouch.  The reasons I gave it four instead of five stars: no gasket on the battery door, no printed manual, backlight is always on.I tested this model side by side with my Bosch and both were accurate. I was not very scientific, and I noticed after the fact that the optics have different set-backs. So even though I aligned the fronts, that was not a fair side by side test.I'd confidently use either model. I had the Bosch first - purchased it because I planned on measuring a lot of exterior distances and wanted that 800 foot range. Found out that in daylight you really need a 2nd person with a reflector for best results. It's easier at dusk when you can see the laser dot. Now that I also have the Stanley, I find the Bosch is overkill for me.  But the next time I need to map out a building, I can hand one of these to my assistant and do it that much faster.
summary: Compact, light, accurate - but only partially water resistant

reviewText: GREAT FOR GENERAL USE AND THE 60 TOOTH BLADE GIVES A NICE SMOOTH CUT TO TRIM BUT IF YOU WANT A REAL PRECISION CUT I WOULD GET A HIGHER TOOTH COUNT THEN 60.

My order arrived on time in an unopened undamaged carton. I bought this for my breezeway & like the idea it automatically goes off. I had a bad habit of forgetting the breezeway light was left on so in the morning it was still on.I would recommend to family & friends
summary: Fulcrum 20031-108 Motion-Sensor LED Porch Light, White

reviewText: Tactix has designed a simple, easy-to-install, sturdy storage system to help you organize your garage, garden shed, or storage space. The 12-piece kit includes the fasttrack bars and screws that you can easily hang on your wall, as well as a variety of utility hooks to hang your bike, hoses, garden tools, shovels, and a hanging basket.It took me between 30-45 minutes to attach the bars to wood supports in my garden shed. All that was required was a cordless drill. The storage kit is sturdy. I put several shovels and/or rakes on some of the utility hooks, and they handled the weight just fine.Tactix has created the kit so that you can use just those utility hooks that you need. If you need additional hooks, they can be purchased separately. Each bar accommodates 3-4 hooks, depending on the size of the utensils you're hanging from them.I highly recommend the kit for anyone who wants to get their tools and other items off the garage floor and up on the wall, and out of the way. It's done wonders for our garden shed.
Use it when traveling in hotels and they don't have a wand shower.  lightweight, drains easily to put back in suitcase.  Happy with the product

I got this for my kitchen to reach the highest shelves way in the back stuff. I am 6ft tall but still couldn't reach everything. I'm a size 16 so I am no small person but well under the weight limit. I have many physical disabities and arthritis and it works well for an older person like me.I tried the stool first thing and it is very sturdy, no wobble or feeling like it was not going to support me. It locks in place when open. I was delighted too to find that it stands freely when closed. I can keep it between the stove and counter so no running to farthest room in the house to get the other step stool.I can highly recommend this product. I might add that I am afraid of heights and I can stand on the top step just fine, one more step and no way I'd do it.

As expected a very high quality tool and well engineered as well.  This tool has saved me a huge amount of time and material especially for remodeling.  Works incredibly well for those awkward cuts on installed material or cutting out material like trim that you can't afford to destroy, or couldn't get a reciprocating saw in without a lot of damage.  I have used this tool to remove sections of painted oak cabinets to include cutting nails, then once my work was done put the removed section where it came from with no one the wiser, using a conventional saw would have destroyed the removed piece and the surrounding face frame too.  I didn't plan on using this as a sander, but the sanding attachments work very, very well.  When looking at the price of this brand vice others really take the attachments into account, a lot of the price is attachments, the cheaper versions aren't nearly the value they may appear to be.
summary: Really excellent tool, a huge value compared to other tools

reviewText: This tool looks and feels great! It was delivered fast and came packaged wrapped in plastic wrap. I like how I can hang it next to my other Purdy paintbrushes with it's soft rubber handle hole. The sharp comb-like cleaning fingers dive into my paint filled paintbrushes with no problem, while allowing regular faucet water pressure to penetrate and clean each layer of the paint. I have not used the roller cleaning portion of this tool, but it sure beats using the area between my thumb and pointer finger to ring out the paint rollers. This is a must have tool for all! I wish I had it earlier though... My reliable Purdy paintbrushes have already stiffened due to my prior cleanings with out this tool.

I am a DIY'er.  I bought this nailer to install Hardieboards on my house.  This tool saved me a huge amount of time over a hammer.However, I am not a pro and here is what I found challenging:1.  The depth gauge was fairly easy to use but after a while I found that I had to just nail in a course and quickly hammer the nails home.  Call it user inexperience (which clearly was the case) but I ended up under-driving rather than over-driving on purpose.2.  If you don't watch the plastic nail strap or cut it off frequently, it could twist around and foul the tool, requiring a stop to fix it.3.  It comes with the "automatic" trigger function: Hold the trigger, push, and nails will pop out until you let go.  I found that difficult to work with: I can see how that would be useful for roofing, but for Hardie Boards, it made me pay too much attention to trigger pull/release, rather than paying attention to quality work.Why 4 stars and not 5: Because the single-trip (one pull, one nail) mechanism doesn't come with the tool.  I had to order that from a Hitachi dealer (referred by Hitachi themselves when I called) and it cost an additional $60-$70.  Porter Cable, for example, will provide a different trip mechanism for free for their finish nailers (or at least they did when I bought one).  This should have been included, or at least the price not so excessive, for such small and few parts.
summary: Great Pro tool but needs focus if you are a DIY'er

reviewText: I bought this to use with a dimmable CF flood over the kitchen sink.  The price was right, and I've installed things like this before.  Installation was a bit confusing, though, thanks in part to the builder-grade original wiring job done in my house 20 years ago (all the wires are black and partly in parallel with an adjacent switch).  I couldn't figure out what needed to connect to what, and this device has an extra wire as well.  A little trial and error, and I didn't burn down the house or even accidentally trip a breaker.

They are cheapo in that they will do a job but not last very long.  I only needed them for a aluminum pipe that is a quarter thick and they did the job flawlessly but after the job they were almost like rubbing plain metal against the aluminum.  If your looking for a long lasting set this isn't the right set for you but if you just have one job and need a good file to do it then these are the best on Amazon.

I'm very satisfied with this faucet and have always respected Moen faucets.Only complaint is that instructions did not show what to do if your hot and cold lines are reversed. After two calls to my plumber( who roughed it in) I found out that you simply remove a metal clip, pull the cartridge out (partially), rotate it 180 deg, push it back in, and reinstall the clip- so simple.

This belt drive opener required more length than my existing chain drive. Unfortunately, I had a 12" x 12" soffit directly behind my existing chain drive motor so I was unable to install this, and I had to return it. I have a friend that installed one in his garage who recommended it to me, and it works great. Ninja quiet.

Not much more to say about this shower than what's in the review title, except that the pressure was quite a bit less than I would have expected. Most likely going to change the shower head out for a handheld that I know has good water pressure.
These brads work well in small projects and fragile nailing. I use them to hold small parts together while the glue drys. they are especially useful in joining irregular shaped pieces together.
summary: Great small to large airdriven brad.

reviewText: This product does what it claims to do and does it well. Not requiring batteries either was a big plus. I have used fairly reasonable stud finders in the past and have to say that this one is the best so far.

Granted most of the use of this device will be related to outdoor use but in a couple situations I found it rather useful to use indoors to confirm that main lines in houses were turned off as well.I have even been able to trace lines in walls with this, though it was a bit difficult I was still able to do it. Mostly though this has been used to check the flow of lines to residential properties to ensure lines are not hot before the crew goes into the houses to start their work. Over the years I've come to be very cautious and not trusting, just because it says it's off doesn't mean it is. Granted most times that's true but for that one in a few thousand times it doesn't hurt to double check all the other times to ensure that no one gets hurt.The amprobe works great for outdoor use as it will squelch pretty loud when it detect power. also when it's on it has a beep every so many seconds to let you know that it is still functioning which I find to be a rather nice feature. The controls are really straight forward and easy to understand. Just hit the bottom for the type of power you want to test and go to town. When in doubt just go from the higher to the lower. As long as you can get withing an inch or 2 of where the wires are you will know for certain if their is power flowing or not.This has helped in finding line damage as well all we had to was walk along the line until the squelch was no longer occurring. Easy peasy really. the only thing I would like better for this is if it didn't use 9V batteries. Granted it does take a while to go through them but still, they get expensive when you have to put a new one in weekly but then again it does serve a really good purpose on the job, a rechargeable option would be nice.
summary: Wow, it works pretty good. just could use a lower beep option for when using indoors.

reviewText: If it was not for the saw dust, I would have had to look to make sure the saw was cutting through the 1-3/4 finger jointed walnut bench top.  I've never used a circular saw blade that cut this smooth with so little effort.  Highly recommend this blade.  Bought it for each of the Dewalt circular saws I gave my sons for Christmas.
Good glove just a little thin but over all good this glove seems to do the job. I would buy again.

The Dado Throat Plate makes my DEWALT DW744XRS table saw even more versatile. It is the perfect woodworking accessory for my 8" Freud dado stack. This throat plate is as well made, as most any DEWALT product, and it promises many generations of use.

Bought it, used it, returned it the following day. Lacks power and endurance even for simple, light duty tasks. I realize it's a cordless saw but for $300 I couldn't have been more  unimpressed. It's equally horrible to the cordless Dewalt I bought ten years ago. You would think cordless saw technology would have gotten better by now. It hasn't. Don't waste your money. Buy something else.
summary: weak, expensive, not a replacement for a corded saw

reviewText: Everything I needed for my path lights: LED ready, Solid build, great price, and clip on wire connectors.Connectors could be a bit longer but that's looking for something to complain about.
summary: Decent construction, Great Price, LED ready

reviewText: I am not going to beat a dead horse by repeating what everyone else has said better than I could. There is nothing about this thermostat that I don't like. It took all of 3/4 hour to install (longer than normal because I repainted the wall). Started right up, downloaded some updates and then it just worked! The first week or two it learns your routine then it takes over and keeps the house temperature just right. For a tech-no-nerd like myself, the apps are the best part. I have the app on a mac mini, an iphone and a kindle. They are identical in appearance and work flawlessly. The coolest thing is the daily report that you receive from Nest tht outlines when the furnace was on, the thermostat changes and why you either used more or less energy. Since it also connects to the weather via the internet, it uses outside temperatures to formulate reasons. Very cool. I don't know yet how much this is going to save me in energy cost. What I will say is that the graph of energy usage is getting shorter over time as the Nest learns our routines. THe goal is to get the little green leaf for the daily energy usage and we get it all the time now. I love this thing!October 2013Almost a year now and I still love it! I am having a new heating and air conditioning system put in and top of the list is that it MUST work with the nest.

When I first saw the commercial for the Dremel Trio on TV my first thought was `cool!' but then I thought `that looks a little like free handing with a router', which I have had bad results doing.  When my wife got the chance to review one for Vine I was thrilled.  After using it a couple of time it turns out my initial impression was pretty close.  Our big project this weekend was to use it do a cutout for the heating register in the  inch laminate flooring we helped my daughter and her husband install.  The tool did the job, but not without some problems.  I think the  inch laminate was too much for the tool/bit.  I was using the TR561 Multi-purpose bit and halfway through the first cut the bit broke.  It was having a hard time going through the material and I was pushing too hard.  I also had the depth set deeper than it need to be.  New bit, less depth and less pressure and I was able to finish it fine, although the last third or so of the cut was really slow going.  I don't know if the laminate was dulling the bit or fouling it, but there was a lot of smoke the last 6 inches.  The next thing we tried it for was to cut a notch.  We cut the two side cuts with a straight saw and then tried to do the inside cut with the Trio.  Broke the bit again.  With all of these cuts I used some sort of guide to run the tool along.  With the register cut it was a 2x4 I keeled on.  With the notch I tried the side fence.  It is very difficult to use this thing free hand.  I was not able to do it, although I am by no means a wood worker.Pros:- Well designed, comfortable tool.- Kit includes a great case with spots for everything including bits and the manual.- The kit includes a side fence, which can also be used to cut circles (which I haven't tried).- Because the tool is small and easy to handle you can use it on projects where you would not be able to use a router.- Adjustable depth, mar-proof foot.Cons:- No two ways about it, this is a router and you have to use it as such.- Bits have a shaft diameter that is different from other Dremel tools (and my router).
They put out a nice blue glowing light.  They are not the brightest, so if that is what you are looking for then look elsewhere.  They just plug in and stay on the whole time, no on/off switch.
summary: Blue glow thats not very bright.

reviewText: Lamp assembles easily. Threads manufactured to fit together well, especially at this price. Nice frosted glass lampshades too. Base is very heavy, so the lamp isn't likely to tip. Lights are 100 watt on top and 40 watt for reading. The reading lamp wouldn't be enough for me but I put in LED lights and they work fine and will cost a lot less in the long-run. I'd would have given the lamp 5 stars, except the reading lamp is adjustable only at the head, rather than the whole arm. It seems like making the arm adjustable would easy and inexpensive.

This tool isnot as good as they say I'm working with wires for 40 years but this tool is garbage because it's not easy to strip  high temperature wire.  Also it slips most of the time trying to strip the wire you don't always get it right the fist time you have to do it some times t2 or 3 times before you can strip the wire.  Don't buy this tool and save your money.
unlike the picture, these do not come wrapped around something, instead they are just shoved into a box so I put then inside sandwich bags

I like to judge products like this based on how intuitive and easy-to-use they are without having the instruction manual.  This one definitely meets the bar!  The large LCD screen shows you the various measurements recorded and computing your area/dimension is simple.  The product description states it is the "world-first" with a calculator, but I could've sworn I've used a Stanley laser-distance measurer that also computed area/squarefeet, etc.  (Though I think I had to refer to the Stanley instruction-manual to figure out how to use it) But hey, who cares!We are looking at moving into a new home in a new school district and having this is fantastic (amongst all of its other uses) to quickly verify and daydream the sizes of rooms, etc as we tour various homes.  Technology has come a long way and I appreciate intuitive, easy-to-use and well-designed products that don't need an instruction manual.

What can we say about the Micra?This is what we like to call a VALUE-DENSE item.Price point?  Excellent.  Uses?  Many.  Construction?  Durable.  Size?  Small, but big enough to use.  Performance?  Nigh flawless.We've been using this for nigh 6 months and this multi-tool has done wonderful.  Although we considered getting others, we opted for this one and we are more than happy.The spring loaded scissors are very useful.  The file is adequate.  The small screwdrivers have their uses while the tweezers work well as well.  Haven't had a chance to use the can opener but am sure it works.Lastly, the knife works well.  Came sharp enough to cut through things although as one reviewer stated push cutting is a bit rough.All in all, its worth the money and it offers a lot of value at competitive pricing.  A true must have if you're looking for a small, affordable pocket multi-tool.

Excellent quality and easy to control. The accompanying documentation was very helpful for blade changes and planning for future accessories. The blades included are of great quality and cover the basics plus.

reviewerName: Bruce Murray On Travel "Murray On Travel"
reviewText: This is a great wide area light.  I have one attached inside a camera bag and use it at night when these bags sometimes feel like a bottomless pit.  I have also used it as a video light at 5ft with some success.
Love Kreg stuff.  Don't really know how much use i'll give this set, but since I'm starting cabinetry , I want this........!

Great for trouble shooting.  After running wires under the house, and having difficulties, it's great to be able to determine where the problem is and isn't.  I've found a number of bad Cat5 connector problems with this tool.  Well worth the price.

I ordered this mitre gauge hoping it would replace a plastic one on a Delta hobby table saw. The bar, which is standard for "normal" table saws, was too wide for my hobby saw which has a 5/8" track. I kept it knowing that I would soon be buying a new table saw. Because the mitre gauge that came with my Sawstop saw is robust enough, I have never bothered to try using this on. I did inspect it, and am convinced it is beautifully made and will be useful...if I ever get around to using it!

Over the years I have always bought blow guns and then drilled out the air passages and connectors for maximum flow.  I have gotten quite good at it, but comparing my custom models to this one, the Typhoon wins hands down.I use Amazon for most of my purchases and update my reviews if anything changes with the products. I do this so other Amazon users can get a real feel for the life of the product. You can look at my review which will be close to my purchase date and tell how the product is doing as time passes.  I am not associated with any company and all opinions are my very own.
summary: Even more powerful than the ones I have bored out

reviewText: I used this for reading in bed--it's far better than those book lights that shine in your eyes.  I really like it--and I'm going to order one for the car.It'd be great for a tent, too.  ;)The batteries have lasted for nearly 30 hours (so far) and going strong.  I use it each night for about 1-2 hours.Great for more than just a camping trip.
Not their best but very nice screw driver set. A bit much but if you use tools all the time its worth the price over the typical sets you can get for $40.

I really like this light so far (3 months). It's really bright for its size and easily operated with one hand. I have had trouble with end button type lights being erratic. This switch seems to be holding up after 3 months of daily use but time will tell. Makes a handy lantern too when the lens is removed. Not as well made as the comparable Fenix model but the maglite can adjust it's beam to broad or spotlight. The brightness of this LED model makes the original solitaires a joke (which they still sell so make sure you get the LED model).
summary: vast improvement from the original solitaire

reviewText: These diamond sharpening bits maintain the same diameter throughout their life.  They seem to run cooler than the abrasive stone bits and produce a smooth finish.  They cut fast initially but if they seem to lose their edge all you need to do is periodically clean them with a cloth wet well with water.  If they've picked up too much oil or pitch you will need to use a solvent like mineral spirits, or diesel fuel to clean them.
This is the flashlight to have. Remember they use plastic lenses so be prepared to get some better glass ones.

We had a large and heavy umbrella that we wanted to be able to move around on our deck.  We bought this mobile base, built a small 32 x 32 deck out of cedar lumber and fastened it to the base.  We lifted the umbrella (it was already assembled) onto the new mobile base and voila!  We move the umbrella with ease around the deck and then lock it down once it is in position.  Even my wife can move this around with no trouble.  I plan to order more as I put my woodshop together.
summary: Works for more than tool bases...

reviewText: Very elegant, modern lamp that looks good in any number of settings. Nice solid weighted base that prevents tipovers. Nice bright LED... nice flexible neck. Switch on cord near lamp is convenient. I love this lamp. Realize, however, that you have to build it yourself from the parts provided, and the base is a fingerprint, dust magnet. It would have been better as a textured surface, but like so much today, it is a shiny black. This is a wonderful high tech lamp that is easy to build.

I've had  this  nailer for over a year and I'm happy with it so far. It is light weight, easy to handle,  easy to add nails and change nails. I'm not a pro so I haven't beat on it.  I've  only used on small jobs; but, have gone through a couple thousand nails  of varies sizes without any nail ever getting jammed. All the nails  I've used have been Bostitch  brand don't know if other brands would work.  I would buy this product again.
summary: I would buy this product again.

reviewText: Streamlight is rated at 24 Lumens verses my old Energizer Pen light's 6 Lumens....used in total darkness is amazing to see well over 100 feet away. Very nice for camping, work and home....I really enjoy having it.This Streamlight is comfortable to carry. Very nice quality feel when handled. I do wish the rubber contact switch tip provided more of an extention to it so I could bite it to hold to use hands free when needed on certain job situations.This Streamlight arrived and right out of the package had good alkaline batteries, the switch worked great unlike I'd read in a couple other reviews.I always sleep with a penlight clipped to the collar of my sleep wear so in an emergency there's no delay seeing in darkness and this light is so bright could be used also to temporarily blind an intruder too.I would not recommmend constantly turning the switch on/ off as I'd suspect that would lead to a malfuntion.This has an easy momentary on/ off touch but as long as this is NOT carried in pants pocket it shouldn't be a worry about depleting the batteries.I do like the momentery touch when it's needed.This does come with a cordura type sheat and a spare rubber cap if the cap does wear through.PLEASE NOTE: when unscrewing the cap to replace batteries, the clip WILL immmediately scratch through the black finish.I would highly recommend this light as I've used pen lights for many years, so far this light has worked great and very bright. I've only had one of these to fail and need replacing, but it had been used extensively and dropped a few times on cement.
I was installing tongue and groove in my house and needed a little help and this machine was more than I expected, I would diffinitely recommend this product

This entry lever was a bit more expensive than others, and there turns out to be a good reason for that slightly higher price. This lever is solid, well made, and great looking. It was easy to install, although the directions were pretty bad. Thus, if this is the first lever that you will be replacing, watch carefully as you take the old lever out of the door, as you won't get much direction from the packaging. But, once installed, you will find this lever to be a tight fit, have a smooth solid feel to its operation and well worth the cost.

Make sure you install 2 of these, so that you'll have a backup, in case the primary gets cut or compromised in some way.  Be CAREFUL when you staple it down, and you'll be set.  Or if you wish to make sure you can't hurt it then use a glue gun, etc.
summary: Excellent!  Make sure you buy 2 - one for the primary and one for a backup "just in case" sensor

reviewText: After viewing the film on the manufacture's site I put the sawhorse to the test.  I was impressed with its set up and the stability of the unit when loaded (on level ground).  The sawhorse served well as the extra hand to hold the log you are cutting.  I discovered why they cut the log on the short side before the longer based side; if you don't have enough weight then the saw & logs weight will let the spike hold free dropping the log.  Watch your toes.Item of concern was the brasses that hold up the top part would come disconnected as you bump the unit while loading the log.  The smallest logs 2-3" were the hardest to wedge in for cutting and to feed the 9+" logs through the opening took some effort.All in all this is a helpful tool if you have to work alone.  Once you get the log in place it is helpful but so is a cradle sawhorse.

Veto PRO PAC makes the best tool bag out there.  I say this after years of using many other brands and designs.  You won't regret this purchcase.  The XL is the perfect size for plumbing service calls.  If you have pride in your work and tools then this tool bag is for you.I bought this bag December 2009.  After reading some of the other reviews I belive that they have corrected some of the issues that affected the older bags.  The handle is tough yet comfortable and the bag is set up to keep all your tools organized and within quick reach.  I do agree with one reviewer who complained that tools catch on the plastic backing along the top row when pulling them out and the plastic should be extended to the bottom of the tool pocket, however, knowing this I don't put tools that catch on the plastic backing in the upper row.  I am now at the point where I "know" where all of the tools are and I can reach for them without looking and get what I need.  This is a great accomplishment, no more stabbing my fingers or digging for my smallest wrench.  The name says it all, this bag is for pros.

Generally LEDs use less power and are brighter than incandescent bulbs, this one is not. It uses 0.5 watt instead of 5w which is a great energy saver but its less bright. It's okay for my application but I was hoping for less wattage and more light just like most other LED applications.
summary: Not as bright as a regular night light bulb

reviewText: This is actually a pretty cool product. My kids had a lot of fun playing music and having the bulb flicker in time to the music; and my daughter saw it could be made pink and immediately wanted it for her room. So, the novelty of it has value.However, the execution is not there. I downloaded the iOS app and it is a hodgepodge of bad design ideas burying interesting features. For example, it's fun to play music and have a light show. However, the lamp itself isn't quite up to the task of changing its brightness or color fast enough to keep up with any reasonable tempo. Also, the act of picking music is clumsy especially if much of your music library is in the cloud; I know people think Coverflows are cool but they are not an efficient means to get through a song library of thousands of pieces.I dislike apps which put up alerts  of the form "Are you sure you want to leave this view without saving your settings." This is just disruptive to the flow of using an app and shows a lack of user experience judgement.While Bluetooth LE is a great technology with many uses, it is likely WiFi would have been more useful. As it is, I have to be close to the lamp to control its settings.As for the lamp itself, it isn't particularly bright even when in its default warm white mode. I wish it pumped out a few more lumens. Don't expect to light an entire room with just this one bulb, especially in color mode.
summary: A Bunch of Features, Unevenly Implemented

reviewText: Excellent light, very bright, long lasting, light weight, and can be used in a lot of configurations.Not at all clear that it comes in "test mode" which means it will automatically turn off after about ten seconds.  I almost returned it thinking it was defective.  Just remove the batteries for a few seconds, put them back in, and you are good to go.
summary: Great light.  Just know that itis delivered in test mode.

reviewText: It works and blocks out the sound. It's light and gives just enough pressure that it fits in your ear snugly but not hurt it. Problem is that when the back portion touches your shoulders/back, it transfers the rubbing sound like a stethoscope. When you walk it sounds like rustling leaves. I don't know how Hickok45 likes it.

There simply are no better blades on the market today than the Forrest line.  Attributes: incredibly well-balanced, quiet, clean cutting, long lasting, excellent packaging, quick and professional resharpening service.  I stray to another brand occasionally, lured by some review in some woodworking magazine, only to be disappointed.  After trying some new "whiz bang" blade that a magazine reviewer touts, I can put even an older Forrest blade back on my equipment and it cuts better than the new "Johnny-come-lately."  Sure, the Forrest blades are a little more expensive, but in this instance, you do truly get what you pay for... and more.  By the way, try Forrest's stabilizer, too.  It will even further enhance performance, especially with a thin kerf blade.

Very nice blade for the radial arm.  Initial jump in is lower and more easily controlled than the prior blade (basic Ryobi blade) and so far the crosscuts in solid red oak board and birch ply have been very smooth and splinter-free.  Ripping in red oak was also smooth although I got just a touch of burning...probably due to me feeding to conservatively.  The blade runs smooth and quiet for the most part; occasionally I get some high pitch shriek but I haven't pinned down whether it is material or thickness...whatever the case it is a lot better than my prior blades so I call it tolerable.  I may try a blade stiffener in the future if it doesn't give up too much depth of cut.As it says in the header I am using this blade on an old but well maintained DeWalt 7779 radial arm saw.
summary: Perfect cuts on my radial arm saw (DeWalt 7779)

reviewText: Go to your local hardware store and buy for half price.  I bought this exact platform today for 39.99, on sale from 45.99.
The Glasses Are Very Clear And Good Fitting As Well. Plus I'm A Big Dewalt Fan It Looks Great With The Rest Of My Stuff.

I bought this flashlight ( http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00JE329YO/ref=oh_details_o07_s00_i00?ie=UTF8&psc;=1 ) which is the same exact flashlight! Just different packaging. But as this other store states it is only a 500 lumen light. And they are telling the truth. It is about a 500 lumen flashlight. Not no 1800! BUT!!! This flashlight that says 1800 lumens is actually about 6 or 7$ cheaper!So if you can stand false advertising then this one would be your bet for around 500 lumens. Not bad for 14 dollars.Other than that!- This flashlight is bright!- Made very well and very sturdy!- It is pretty nice to be able to use both AAA and 18650 batteries with this light.- 5 modes - high med low strobe and SOS- It zooms in and out very far! It zooms in so far that it makes the shape of the LED itself!- Press half-way on the button to change modes. Press All the way down to stay in High mode.NOTE! The battery mine came with lasts 30 whole minutes on high! They come with s*** 1800 Mah blue generic 18650 batteries. I would buy better ones! Or use high dollar AAA.
summary: Bought from more reliable Store. It is a 500 Lumen Flashlight.

reviewText: This sharpener is a beast. It very quickly restored a good edge to some of my older knives. Be cautioned however, as others note it does take a lot of material off the blade quickly, so do not over use it. Only a couple of strokes are necessary.
A great flashlight. Extremely powerful. Uses 4 AA batteries and delivers more light than any other flashlights excetpt for a Helicopter Police lighting.

Why would anyone need yet another flashlight? I have a plethora, it seems, of traditional battery-powered ones of different sizes and one large rechargeable one.  But, to my delight and surprise, this one from OXA beats them all.  Fully charged in a couple of hours, I have used it almost daily for nearly a month now. The beam is REALLY bright and, although not adjustable, illuminates things better than my trusty old (former stand-by) the Maglite.It fits nicely in my hand and is simple to operate - it is simply ON or Off.The only drawback I find with it is that unlike many other rechargeable devices, it has a proprietary charging cable and does not accept the mini-USB port in generally common use in rechargeable devices (except, of course, for Apple products.)A fine utility to have around the house! I recommend it highly - and have given it four stars only because of the idiosyncratic charging cable that makes it necessary to bring it along when on the road.

We moved into a new apartment. While I appreciate the low flow toilet anything larger than, well, normal stops everything. This plunger is just right. Fits the opening making for a successful unclogging without all of the mess.

This is a solid dimmer which I used for a floor lamp in my bedroom. It dims evenly and without causing a hum as most do. The sliding switch will stop moving before it is "off." I can't tell if this means that light is completely off, but the green LED on the controlled is not lit, or if I must move it far enough for the LED to light to be completely off.
Great for hanging larger pictures, decorative plates, etc. without having to poke holes in your walls. I absolutely love them.

I used the bit holder to put in several dozen self-drilling Phillips head screws.  It worked well and I could not detect any wobble.  Magnet is not as strong as other holders I have used, but is adequate.
summary: Works well, magnet could be stronger

reviewText: These work great in ceiling fans. I'm sick of the new laws making ceiling fans use crap bulbs.
